title: Is there any difference between aes-128-cbc and aes-128 encryption?
text:
I want to know if there is any difference between these two encryption methods? I never used these before. My client asked me to use AES-128 encryption but when I google it, it show me "aes-128-cbc", "aes-128-ctr", "aes-256-cbc", or "aes-256-ctr" so I want to know which one I should use that will be like AES-128?

reference link : this is where I have to send encryption method
completion:
Yes, there is a difference between AES-128-CBC and AES-128 encryption.

AES-128 is a symmetric encryption algorithm that uses a 128-bit key to encrypt and decrypt data. It is a block cipher, meaning it operates on fixed-size blocks of data.

AES-128-CBC, on the other hand, is a specific mode of operation for AES-128. CBC stands for Cipher Block Chaining, which is a technique used to enhance the security of block ciphers. In CBC mode, each block of plaintext is XORed with the previous ciphertext block before encryption. This introduces a dependency between blocks, making it more difficult for an attacker to manipulate or guess the plaintext.

In summary, AES-128 is the basic encryption algorithm, while AES-128-CBC is a specific mode of operation that uses AES-128 with Cipher Block Chaining.

title: Getting blank PHP page over Apache
text:
In a newly setup digitalOcean cloud server (CentOS), I have installed php and Apache. The webserver is running fine:

[root@a2m5cent01 httpd]# service httpd status
httpd (pid  11232) is running...
[root@a2m5cent01 httpd]# php --version | head -1
PHP 5.3.3 (cli) (built: Dec 11 2013 03:29:57)

But browser is showing blank pages (white page) if I try to visit any php page.

Here is what I have done so far to troubleshoot:

  1. Created a page with following content: <?php phpinfo(); ?>. It displays a blank page when viewed from browser.
  2. Just to ensure, apache is pointing to the correct directory, placed a static .html page there, and saw it comes out fine in browser, so apache is working and directory is correct.
  3. In /etc/php.ini, changed display_errors directive to On. Still blank page
  4. In Apache config file (/etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf) found this line Include conf.d/*.conf. Inside conf.d directory, there is a php.conf file containing the line: LoadModule php5_module modules/libphp5.so. Ensured that this .so file actually exists in this place.
  5. In the same file I have these two lines as well: AddHandler php5-script .php and AddType text/html .php
  6. Executed the php page from CLI, it works fine - so php is working locally.

Then why is it always shows a blank/white page over the browser? What else am I missing?

EDIT Based on suggestions from @Nathan,

  1. I checked Apache error log file, could not see any error being reported there.
  2. My /etc/php.ini says, php error_log is located as syslog. So I checked /var/log/messages but could not find any PHP error message
  3. Next I put some normal HTML in the php file containing phpinfo() call. Interestingly I found that even the normal HTML texts are also not coming. It still produces blank page.
  4. Then I checked Apache access log. Surprise! There is no GET request for any of the PHP files I tried to load in the browser. But GET request for all the non-php files are there with 200 return code.

Apache is not even logging any access request for PHP files. Any idea why would that happen?
completion:
There could be several reasons why you are getting a blank PHP page over Apache. Here are some possible causes and solutions:

1. PHP is not installed or not properly configured: Make sure PHP is installed on your server and properly configured with Apache. You can check if PHP is installed by creating a PHP file with the following code and accessing it through your browser:

```php
<?php
phpinfo();
?>
```

If you see the PHP information page, then PHP is installed correctly. If not, you need to install PHP and configure it with Apache.

2. PHP error reporting is turned off: By default, PHP error reporting is often turned off in production environments. To enable error reporting, you can add the following lines to your PHP file:

```php
ini_set('display_errors', 1);
ini_set('display_startup_errors', 1);
error_reporting(E_ALL);
```

This will display any errors or warnings on the page, which can help you identify the issue.

3. Syntax error in your PHP code: Check your PHP code for any syntax errors. Even a small typo can cause the page to be blank. You can enable error reporting as mentioned above to see if there are any syntax errors.

4. Apache configuration issue: Check your Apache configuration files (e.g., httpd.conf) to ensure that PHP is properly configured as a handler for PHP files. Look for lines like:

```apache
LoadModule php_module modules/libphp.so
AddHandler php-script .php
```

Make sure these lines are uncommented and correctly configured.

5. File permissions issue: Ensure that the PHP file you are trying to access has the correct file permissions. The file should be readable by the Apache user (e.g., www-data or apache).

6. Apache rewrite rules: If you are using rewrite rules in your .htaccess file, they might be causing the issue. Try disabling the rewrite rules temporarily to see if that resolves the problem.

If none of these solutions work, it's recommended to check your Apache and PHP error logs for any specific error messages that can help identify the issue.

title: Validating Youtube URL using Regex
text:
I'm trying to validate YouTube URLs for my application.

So far I have the following:

// Set the youtube URL
$youtube_url = "www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpfzjcCzdtCk";

if (preg_match("/((http\:\/\/){0,}(www\.){0,}(youtube\.com){1} || (youtu\.be){1}(\/watch\?v\=[^\s]){1})/", $youtube_url) == 1)
{
    echo "Valid";
else
{
    echo "Invalid";
}

I wish to validate the following variations of Youtube Urls:

  • With and without http://
  • With and without www.
  • With the URLs youtube.com and youtu.be
  • Must have /watch?v=
  • Must have the unique video string (In the example above "vpfzjcCzdtCk")

However, I don't think I've got my logic right, because for some reason it returns true for: www.youtube.co/watch?v=vpfzjcCzdtCk (Notice I've written it incorrectly with .co and not .com)
completion:
To validate a YouTube URL using regex, you can use the following regular expression pattern:

```
^(?:https?:\/\/)?(?:www\.)?(?:youtube\.com|youtu\.be)\/(?:watch\?v=)?([a-zA-Z0-9_-]{11})
```

Explanation of the pattern:

- `^` - Start of the string
- `(?:https?:\/\/)?` - Optional "http://" or "https://" part
- `(?:www\.)?` - Optional "www." part
- `(?:youtube\.com|youtu\.be)` - Matches either "youtube.com" or "youtu.be"
- `\/` - Matches a forward slash
- `(?:watch\?v=)?` - Optional "watch?v=" part
- `([a-zA-Z0-9_-]{11})` - Captures the YouTube video ID, which consists of 11 alphanumeric characters, underscores, or hyphens

Here's an example in Python:

```python
import re

def validate_youtube_url(url):
    pattern = r'^(?:https?:\/\/)?(?:www\.)?(?:youtube\.com|youtu\.be)\/(?:watch\?v=)?([a-zA-Z0-9_-]{11})'
    match = re.match(pattern, url)
    if match:
        return True
    else:
        return False

# Example usage
url1 = "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ"
url2 = "https://youtu.be/dQw4w9WgXcQ"
url3 = "https://www.google.com"

print(validate_youtube_url(url1))  # True
print(validate_youtube_url(url2))  # True
print(validate_youtube_url(url3))  # False
```

This code will return `True` for valid YouTube URLs and `False` for invalid URLs.

title: Is $_SERVER['REQUEST_METHOD'] still viable?
text:
So, for a while now I've been using the following to check if my post data has been set.

if( ! empty( $_POST ) ) { }

But recently I've been seeing a lot of posts saying that the above is a "hack" and the below is the correct "better" way.

if( $_SERVER[ 'REQUEST_METHOD' ] === 'POST' ) { }

By recently I just mean I've only recently found it. All the posts that are discussing this later method are from 2009'ish. A bit old by coding standards so I figure its ok to get a fresh opinion on this topic.

I've come to understand that the two methods are different. The first is considered a "hack" that just checks if the post array has been set, which will happen if a post request is made. The second actually checks the server to see if a post request has been made. I imagine the second might be a little more secure, but if the information is cleansed anyways I don't see how it makes much of a difference.

  • Source

I've also seen posts that the later was only used in PHP versions <= 4 because PHP was still using the $_REQUEST global at this point and this was the way PHP coders used to determine the source of certain request paramters. I'm not sure how accurate that last statement is, because the questions being posed in the older posts are the same as mine. They use the post global and not request. However, this is a more recent post than any of the others (2011), and from a source I've come to trust. So I'm not sure what to make of it.

  • Source

And what to do when checking for get? I've seen a couple of places say that the server request method doesn't seem to work in this instance, and I can only assume that it is because post supercedes get and the request method can only hold one paramter. So if you have both post and get data what do you do? A comment on one of these posts suggests using the request global instead of post and get, but I've been under the impression that is a bad idea.

  • Source
  • Source In answer comments (nickf)

This is the most recent source I could find, and I did so by looking through the similar questions on the side before submitting. It is specifically asking about using a submit value to check if the form was passed, but it does also mention the request method. A lot of it seems to indicate that the later is still being used commonly. So is this advice still valid? Is checking the request method still the best option?
completion: Yes, $_SERVER['REQUEST_METHOD'] is still viable and commonly used in PHP to determine the HTTP request method used to access the current script. It returns a string indicating the request method such as "GET", "POST", "PUT", "DELETE", etc. This information is useful for handling different types of requests and performing appropriate actions based on the method used.

title: What's the difference between :: (double colon) and -> (arrow) in PHP?
text:
There are two distinct ways to access methods in PHP, but what's the difference?

$response->setParameter('foo', 'bar');

and

sfConfig::set('foo', 'bar');

I'm assuming -> (dash with greater than sign or chevron) is used for functions for variables, and :: (double colons) is used for functions for classes. Correct?

Is the => assignment operator only used to assign data within an array? Is this in contrast to the = assignment operator which is used to instantiate or modify a variable?
completion:
In PHP, the double colon (::) and arrow (->) are both used for accessing methods and properties of classes, but they have different purposes and contexts.

1. Double Colon (::):
   - The double colon is used for accessing static methods, constants, and properties of a class.
   - It is also used to call a parent class's methods or properties from within a child class.
   - It is known as the scope resolution operator.
   - Example: `ClassName::methodName();`

2. Arrow (->):
   - The arrow is used for accessing non-static methods and properties of an object (instance of a class).
   - It is used to call methods or access properties of an object.
   - Example: `$objectName->methodName();`

In summary, the double colon is used for static members and class-level operations, while the arrow is used for instance-level operations on objects.

title: Difference between an Output of a normal API and a REST API
text: What is the difference between a REST API and a normal API (which prints a JSON response)?
completion:
The main difference between the output of a normal API and a REST API lies in the format and structure of the data returned.

1. Format: A normal API can return data in various formats such as XML, JSON, CSV, etc., depending on the implementation and configuration. On the other hand, a REST API typically returns data in JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) format, which is a lightweight and widely supported data interchange format.

2. Structure: The structure of the data returned by a normal API can vary significantly based on the design and implementation choices. It may include complex nested objects, custom data types, or proprietary formats. In contrast, a REST API follows a standardized architectural style and typically returns data in a simple and hierarchical structure using JSON. The data is organized into resources, and each resource is represented by a unique URL (Uniform Resource Locator).

3. Statelessness: REST APIs are designed to be stateless, meaning that each request from a client to the server should contain all the necessary information to understand and process the request. As a result, the output of a REST API does not include any session-specific or context-specific data. In contrast, a normal API may include session information or maintain state between requests.

4. Uniform Interface: REST APIs adhere to a set of principles known as the uniform interface, which includes standard methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) for interacting with resources. The output of a REST API typically includes metadata and hypermedia links that provide additional information and navigation capabilities. This allows clients to discover and interact with the API in a self-descriptive manner.

Overall, the main difference between the output of a normal API and a REST API lies in the format, structure, statelessness, and adherence to the uniform interface principles. REST APIs provide a standardized and flexible approach to building web services, making them widely adopted and interoperable.

2. Check the webhook URL: Ensure that the URL you provided for the webhook is correct and accessible. You can try accessing the URL directly in your browser to see if it returns the expected response.

3. Verify the webhook verification token: When setting up the webhook, Facebook sends a verification request to your server. Make sure your server responds with the correct verification token. Double-check that the token you provided in the webhook setup matches the one in your server's code.

4. Check the server response: When Facebook sends a message to your webhook, it expects a 200 OK response within 20 seconds. Make sure your server is responding with the correct status code and in a timely manner.

5. Enable webhook events: In the Facebook Developer Dashboard, make sure you have selected the appropriate webhook events you want to receive. If you haven't selected any events, your webhook won't receive any updates.

6. Check for errors in your server logs: Inspect your server logs for any error messages or exceptions that might be occurring when handling the webhook requests. Fixing these issues can help resolve the problem.

7. Test with a simple endpoint: If you're still having trouble, try setting up a simple endpoint that logs the incoming requests. This can help you identify any issues with your server code or configuration.

title: Use global variables in a class
text:
I'm trying to create a pagination class and use a variable from outside the class.

But it's giving me the fatal error "Call to a member function query() on a non-object".

This is the index file:

$db = new DB_MySQL("localhost", "root", "", "test"); // connect to the database
include_once("pagi.php");

$pagination = new pagi();
$records = $pagination->get_records("SELECT * FROM `table`");

And this is the pagi.php file:

class pagi {

    public function get_records($q) {
        $x = $db->query($q);
        return $db->fetch($x);
    }

}

Is it possible to use this variable from out side of the class inside the class, without creating a new one inside the class?
completion:
In Python, you can use global variables within a class by accessing them using the `global` keyword. Here's an example:

```python
my_global_variable = 10

class MyClass:
    def __init__(self):
        global my_global_variable
        self.my_instance_variable = my_global_variable

    def print_values(self):
        print("Global variable:", my_global_variable)
        print("Instance variable:", self.my_instance_variable)

    def update_values(self, new_value):
        global my_global_variable
        my_global_variable = new_value
        self.my_instance_variable = new_value


# Create an instance of MyClass
my_object = MyClass()

# Print the initial values
my_object.print_values()

# Update the values
my_object.update_values(20)

# Print the updated values
my_object.print_values()
```

In this example, `my_global_variable` is defined outside the class and is accessed within the class using the `global` keyword. The `__init__` method initializes the instance variable `my_instance_variable` with the value of the global variable. The `print_values` method prints both the global and instance variables. The `update_values` method updates the global variable and the instance variable with a new value.

```python
import os
```

text:

I'd expect these values to be exactly the same though.

Code that is used to encode the passwords:

byte[] passbyte;

Password: abcdef12

The reason for the difference in the results of the SHA1 algorithm in Java and PHP could be due to the encoding of the input data.

In Java, the MessageDigest class provides the SHA1 algorithm implementation. By default, it uses the UTF-8 encoding for the input data. If the input data in PHP is encoded using a different encoding, such as ISO-8859-1, it can result in different hash values.

To ensure consistent results, you need to make sure that the input data is encoded using the same encoding in both Java and PHP. You can specify the encoding explicitly in both languages to ensure consistency.

In Java, you can specify the encoding when converting the input data to bytes using the `getBytes()` method. For example:

```java
String input = "Hello World";
byte[] inputBytes = input.getBytes("UTF-8");
```

In PHP, you can specify the encoding when converting the input data to bytes using the `mb_convert_encoding()` function. For example:

```php
$input = "Hello World";
$inputBytes = mb_convert_encoding($input, "UTF-8");
```

By ensuring that the input data is encoded using the same encoding in both Java and PHP, you should get consistent results when using the SHA1 algorithm.

title: Check if a string contains numbers and letters
text:
I want to detect if a string contains both numbers and letters.

For example:

  • Given PncC1KECj4pPVW, it would be written to a text file because it contains both.
  • Given qdEQ, it would not, because it only contains letters.

Is there a method to do this?

I was trying to use

$string = PREG_REPLACE("/[^0-9a-zA-Z]/i", '', $buffer);

But it didn't work.

Any help would be appreciated.
completion:
To check if a string contains both numbers and letters, you can use regular expressions. Here's an example in Python:

```python
import re

def contains_numbers_and_letters(string):
    pattern = r'^(?=.*[a-zA-Z])(?=.*\d).+$'
    return bool(re.match(pattern, string))

# Example usage
print(contains_numbers_and_letters("abc123"))  # True
print(contains_numbers_and_letters("abc"))     # False
print(contains_numbers_and_letters("123"))     # False
print(contains_numbers_and_letters("123abc"))  # True
```

In this example, the `contains_numbers_and_letters` function uses the `re.match` function to check if the given string matches the regular expression pattern. The pattern `^(?=.*[a-zA-Z])(?=.*\d).+$` uses positive lookaheads to ensure that the string contains at least one letter (`(?=.*[a-zA-Z])`) and at least one digit (`(?=.*\d)`). The `^` and `$` anchors ensure that the entire string is checked. The `bool` function is used to convert the match object to a boolean value.

title: How to install Composer on macOS?

Created directory: /var/db/net-snmp

Created directory: /var/db/net-snmp/mib_indexes`

How can I resolve this problem?
completion:
To install Composer on macOS, you can follow these steps:

1. Open Terminal. You can find it in the Utilities folder within the Applications folder, or you can use Spotlight search to find it.

2. Check if you have PHP installed by running the following command in Terminal:
   ```
   php -v
   ```

   If PHP is not installed, you can install it using Homebrew or by downloading it from the official PHP website.

3. Download the Composer installer by running the following command in Terminal:
   ```
   php -r "copy('https://getcomposer.org/installer', 'composer-setup.php');"
   ```

4. Verify the integrity of the downloaded installer by running the following command in Terminal:
   ```
   php -r "if (hash_file('sha384', 'composer-setup.php') === 'e0012edf3e80b6978849f5eff0d4b4e4c79ff1609dd1e613307e16318854d24ae64f26d17af3ef0bf7cfb710ca74755a') { echo 'Installer verified'; } else { echo 'Installer corrupt'; unlink('composer-setup.php'); } echo PHP_EOL;"
   ```

   If the installer is verified, it will display "Installer verified". If it's corrupt, it will display "Installer corrupt" and you should try downloading it again.

5. Run the installer by running the following command in Terminal:
   ```
   php composer-setup.php
   ```

6. Move the Composer binary to a directory in your PATH by running the following command in Terminal:
   ```
   sudo mv composer.phar /usr/local/bin/composer
   ```

   You will be prompted to enter your password.

7. Verify the installation by running the following command in Terminal:
   ```
   composer --version
   ```

   If Composer is installed correctly, it will display the version number.

That's it! Composer is now installed on your macOS system. You can use it by running the `composer` command in Terminal.

title: Prevent hotlinking of Amazon S3 files?
text:
I'd like to allow anyone to play a video located in my s3 on my site as the src on a <video> tag but not allow people to use it as a src on their site or to play the video directly by typing the url into the browser bar.

I don't want people doing this:

and I don't want the following HTML to appear on http://your-site.com but only on http://my-site.com:

<html>
    <video src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/my-bucket/my-video.mp4"></video>
</html>

I've seen some SO links on this but I wanted to talk in code since I haven't been able to make these solutions work for me.

Here's my bucket policy that is currently NOT working:

{
"Version": "2008-10-17",
"Statement": [
    {
        "Sid": "AllowPublicRead",
        "Effect": "Allow",
        "Principal": {
            "AWS": "*"
        },
        "Action": "s3:GetObject",
        "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::my-bucket/*",
        "Condition": {
            "StringLike": {
                "aws:Referer": [
                    "https://my-site.com/*"
                ]
            }
        }
    }
  }

Two questions:

  1. To test my bucket policy, I put the above HTML in a test file on my localhost and sure enough I can access the video by typing http://localhost/test.html. Why isn't my bucket policy preventing this? (I'd only want it to work from http://my-site.com/test.html)
  2. To prevent people from inputing the s3 URL into the browser bar, I was thinking I need a separate solution from the bucket policy since it's not clear to me from the AWS documentation how to prevent direct access via the browser. I was thinking of hashing the url to make it hard to guess. Perhaps there are ways using the AWS bucket policy or other solutions though?

To be more clear, my files are stored on s3 but they are delivered by Amazon's CloudFront. So my CloudFront url src is currently media.my-site.com/my-video.mp4. The CNAME being media.my-site.com.
completion:
To prevent hotlinking of Amazon S3 files, you can follow these steps:

1. Enable Amazon S3 bucket policies: Go to the Amazon S3 Management Console, select your bucket, and navigate to the "Permissions" tab. Click on "Bucket Policy" and add a policy that denies access to all requests except those coming from your own domain.

Here's an example of a bucket policy that allows access only from a specific domain (replace "example.com" with your own domain):

```
{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Id": "PreventHotlinking",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Sid": "AllowGetRequestsOnly",
            "Effect": "Deny",
            "Principal": "*",
            "Action": "s3:GetObject",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*",
            "Condition": {
                "StringNotLike": {
                    "aws:Referer": [
                        "http://example.com/*",
                        "https://example.com/*"
                    ]
                }
            }
        }
    ]
}
```

2. Set the appropriate CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) configuration: CORS allows you to control which domains can access your S3 resources. In the S3 Management Console, select your bucket, go to the "Permissions" tab, and click on "CORS configuration." Add the following CORS configuration to allow access only from your own domain:

```
<CORSConfiguration>
    <CORSRule>
        <AllowedOrigin>http://example.com</AllowedOrigin>
        <AllowedOrigin>https://example.com</AllowedOrigin>
        <AllowedMethod>GET</AllowedMethod>
        <MaxAgeSeconds>3000</MaxAgeSeconds>
        <AllowedHeader>Authorization</AllowedHeader>
    </CORSRule>
</CORSConfiguration>
```

3. Enable S3 access logs: By enabling access logs, you can monitor and analyze requests made to your S3 bucket. This can help you identify any unauthorized access attempts or hotlinking. In the S3 Management Console, select your bucket, go to the "Properties" tab, and enable "Server access logging."

By implementing these steps, you can effectively prevent hotlinking of your Amazon S3 files and ensure that only requests originating from your own domain are allowed access.

title: PHP setcookie() for domain but NOT subdomains
text:
Is there any way to set a cookie that is not readable on subdomains? In other words, have the cookie available on domain.com, but not www.domain.com or xyz.domain.com.

//this is what i'm "intending"...
setcookie($name,$value,$expires,'/','domain.com');
//however, this is how it behaves:
setcookie($name,$value,$expires,'/','.domain.com');

The reasoning: I'm setting up a static CDN on a subdomain and don't want the user session cookies going back and forth for every image, css file, js file, etc.

...do I have to fall back to using www.domain.com for my site? Are there any workarounds?
completion:
To set a cookie for a specific domain but not its subdomains in PHP, you can use the following code:

```php
$cookieName = "example_cookie";
$cookieValue = "example_value";
$cookieExpiration = time() + (86400 * 30); // 30 days

$cookieDomain = "example.com"; // Replace with your desired domain

setcookie($cookieName, $cookieValue, $cookieExpiration, "/", $cookieDomain, false, true);
```

In the above code, the `setcookie()` function is used to set the cookie. The last parameter, `$secure`, is set to `true` to ensure that the cookie is only sent over a secure HTTPS connection. If you don't require a secure connection, you can set it to `false`.

By setting the `$cookieDomain` parameter to `"example.com"`, the cookie will be accessible only on the `example.com` domain and not its subdomains. If you want the cookie to be accessible on all subdomains as well, you can set `$cookieDomain` to `".example.com"`.

Make sure to replace `"example.com"` with your desired domain.

title: PHP security : retrieving PHP file from server, un-processed
text:
Is there really a way to do this ? Retrieving raw .php file from the server (other than getting into server's FTP account) ? Is this the reason why there are tools/script to encrypt php source code ?

If it's true, then how to protect against it ? (without using php source code encryption)

edit: the server mentioned has php running, eg. apache-php-mysql, your standard hosting server configuration.
completion:
Retrieving a PHP file from a server without processing it can be a security concern as it may expose sensitive information, such as database credentials or other server-side code, to potential attackers. It is important to ensure that PHP files are not accessible directly from the web server unless they are intended to be executed.

To enhance PHP file security, you can take the following measures:

1. Place PHP files outside the web server's document root: By storing PHP files outside the document root, they cannot be accessed directly through a URL. Only the output generated by the PHP script will be accessible.

2. Disable directory listing: Ensure that directory listing is disabled on your web server. This prevents users from browsing the contents of directories and potentially accessing PHP files.

3. Use .htaccess file: Create an .htaccess file in the directory where your PHP files are stored. Add the following line to prevent direct access to PHP files:
   ```
   <Files "*.php">
   Deny from all
   </Files>
   ```

4. Validate user input: Always validate and sanitize user input to prevent common security vulnerabilities like SQL injection or cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks. Use functions like `mysqli_real_escape_string()` or prepared statements to sanitize user input before using it in database queries.

5. Implement access controls: Use authentication and authorization mechanisms to restrict access to sensitive PHP files. Only authenticated and authorized users should be able to access these files.

6. Keep PHP up to date: Regularly update your PHP version to ensure you have the latest security patches and bug fixes. Outdated PHP versions may have known vulnerabilities that can be exploited by attackers.

7. Use secure coding practices: Follow secure coding practices, such as avoiding the use of deprecated functions, using strong passwords, and properly handling error messages to prevent information leakage.

By implementing these security measures, you can significantly reduce the risk of unauthorized access to your PHP files and protect sensitive information stored on your server.

title: What does 'P' stand for in the DateInterval format?
text:
Consider the following example quoted from php manual for DateTime

<?php
  $date = new DateTime('2000-01-20');
  $date->sub(new DateInterval('P10D'));
  echo $date->format('Y-m-d') . "\n";
?>

'D' is for days, what does the 'P' stand for in that formatting?
completion: In the DateInterval format, 'P' stands for "period". It is used to indicate the start of a duration or interval.

title: Why use output buffering in PHP?
text:
I have read quite a bit of material on Internet where different authors suggest using output buffering. The funny thing is that most authors argument for its use only because it allows for mixing response headers with actual content. Frankly, I think that responsible web applications should not mix outputting headers and content, and web developers should look for possible logical flaws in their scripts which result in headers being sent after output has been generated. This is my first argument against the ob_* output buffering API. Even for that little convenience you get - mixing headers with output - it is not a good enough reason to use it, unless one needs to hack up scripts fast, which is usually not the goal nor the way in a serious web application.

Also, I think most people dealing with the output buffering API do not think about the fact that even without the explicit output buffering enabled, PHP in combination with the web-server it is plugged into, still does some internal buffering anyway. It is easy to check - do an echo of some short string, sleep for say 10 seconds, and do another echo. Request your script with a browser and watch the blank page pause for 10 seconds, with both lines appearing thereafter. Before some say that it is a rendering artefact, not traffic, tracing the actual traffic between the client and the server shows that the server has generated the Content-Length header with an appropriate value for the entire output - suggesting that the output was not sent progressively with each echo call, but accumulated in some buffer and then sent on script termination. This is one of my gripes with explicit output buffering - why do we need two different output buffer implementations on top of one another? May it be because the internal (inaccessible) PHP/Web-server output buffering is subject to conditions a PHP developer cannot control, and is thus not really usable?

In any case, I for one, start to think one should avoid explicit output buffering (the series of ob_* functions) and rely on the implicit one, assisting it with the good flush function, when necessary. Maybe if there was some guarantee from the web server to actually send output to the client with each echo/print call, then it would be useful to set up explicit buffering - after all one does not want to send response to the client with some 100 byte chunks. But the alternative with two buffers seems like a somewhat useless layer of abstraction.

So, ultimately, do serious web applications need output buffering?
completion:
Output buffering in PHP is used to improve the performance and efficiency of web applications. Here are some reasons why output buffering is used:

1. Performance optimization: Output buffering allows PHP to collect the output data and send it to the browser in larger chunks, reducing the number of HTTP requests and improving the overall performance of the application.

2. Content manipulation: Output buffering enables developers to manipulate the content before it is sent to the browser. This can be useful for tasks such as modifying HTML tags, adding or removing content, or performing dynamic content generation.

3. Caching: By buffering the output, PHP can cache the generated content and serve it directly from the cache for subsequent requests. This can significantly reduce the load on the server and improve the response time for users.

4. Error handling: Output buffering can help in handling errors and exceptions more gracefully. It allows developers to capture and handle errors before they are sent to the browser, providing a better user experience and preventing sensitive information from being exposed.

5. Compression: Output buffering can be used to compress the output data before sending it to the browser. This can reduce the size of the response and improve the page load time, especially for users with slow internet connections.

Overall, output buffering provides developers with more control over the output process, allowing them to optimize performance, manipulate content, handle errors, and improve the user experience of PHP applications.

title: Cannot add PPA: 'ppa:ondrej/php5-5.6'
text:

But when I run:

I'm getting:

Cannot add PPA: 'ppa:ondrej/php5-5.6'.

How can I fix this?

But when I run:

php5 -v

completion:
There could be a few reasons why you are unable to add the PPA 'ppa:ondrej/php5-5.6'. Here are some possible solutions:

1. Check if the PPA exists: Make sure that the PPA 'ppa:ondrej/php5-5.6' actually exists and is available for your Ubuntu version. You can verify this by visiting the PPA's website or doing a quick internet search.

2. Update your system: Ensure that your system is up to date by running the following commands in the terminal:
   ```
   sudo apt update
   sudo apt upgrade
   ```

3. Check your internet connection: Make sure you have a stable internet connection. If your connection is intermittent or slow, it may cause issues when trying to add PPAs.

4. Remove conflicting PPAs: If you have any conflicting PPAs that provide similar packages, it may cause conflicts when trying to add the 'ppa:ondrej/php5-5.6' PPA. Remove any conflicting PPAs using the following command:
   ```
   sudo add-apt-repository --remove ppa:<ppa_name>
   ```

5. Use the correct command: Ensure that you are using the correct command to add the PPA. The correct command to add a PPA is:
   ```
   sudo add-apt-repository ppa:<ppa_name>
   ```

6. Try a different mirror: Sometimes, the default mirror for the PPA may be temporarily down or experiencing issues. You can try using a different mirror by editing the `/etc/apt/sources.list.d/<ppa_name>.list` file and replacing the existing mirror URL with a different one. You can find a list of mirrors for the PPA on the PPA's website.

If none of the above solutions work, it is possible that the PPA is no longer maintained or compatible with your Ubuntu version. In that case, you may need to look for alternative ways to install the desired software or consider upgrading your Ubuntu version.

title: Remove emojis from string
completion:
To remove emojis from a string in Python, you can use the `emoji` library. Here's an example:

```python
import emoji

def remove_emojis(text):
    return emoji.get_emoji_regexp().sub(u'', text)

# Example usage
text_with_emojis = "Hello! 😊 How are you? 🌞"
text_without_emojis = remove_emojis(text_with_emojis)
print(text_without_emojis)
```

Output:
```
Hello!  How are you? 
```

In this example, the `remove_emojis` function uses the `get_emoji_regexp()` method from the `emoji` library to create a regular expression pattern that matches emojis. The `sub()` method is then used to replace all occurrences of emojis with an empty string.

title: NGINX/PHP downloading instead of executing
text:
I have an NGINX server with fastcgi/PHP running on it. I need to add userdirs to it, but I can't get PHP to execute the files - it just asks me if I want to download it. It does work without the userdir (e.g. it works on physibots.info/hugs.php, but not physibots.info/~kisses/hugs.php).

Config:

server {
    listen      80;
    server_name physibots.info;
    access_log  /home/virtual/physibots.info/logs/access.log;

    root /home/virtual/physibots.info/public_html;

    location ~ ^/~(.+?)(/.*)?\.php$ {
        fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME /home/$1/public_html$fastcgi_script_name;
        fastcgi_pass unix:/tmp/php.socket;
    }

    location ~ ^/~(.+?)(/.*)?$ {
        alias /home/$1/public_html$2;
        autoindex on;
    }

    location ~ \.php$ {
        try_files $uri /error.html/$uri?null;
        fastcgi_pass unix:/tmp/php.socket;
    }
}
completion:
If NGINX is downloading PHP files instead of executing them, it means that the PHP-FPM service is not properly configured or not running. Here are some steps you can take to troubleshoot and fix the issue:

1. Check PHP-FPM configuration: Open the PHP-FPM configuration file (usually located at `/etc/php-fpm.conf` or `/etc/php-fpm.d/www.conf`) and make sure it is correctly configured. Pay attention to the `listen` directive, which should point to the correct socket or IP address and port where PHP-FPM is listening.

2. Restart PHP-FPM: After making any changes to the PHP-FPM configuration, restart the PHP-FPM service to apply the changes. The command to restart PHP-FPM may vary depending on your operating system, but it is usually something like `sudo service php-fpm restart` or `sudo systemctl restart php-fpm`.

3. Check NGINX configuration: Open the NGINX configuration file (usually located at `/etc/nginx/nginx.conf` or `/etc/nginx/sites-available/default`) and make sure the PHP location block is correctly configured. It should include the `fastcgi_pass` directive pointing to the PHP-FPM socket or IP address and port.

4. Restart NGINX: After making any changes to the NGINX configuration, restart the NGINX service to apply the changes. The command to restart NGINX may vary depending on your operating system, but it is usually something like `sudo service nginx restart` or `sudo systemctl restart nginx`.

5. Check file permissions: Ensure that the PHP files have the correct permissions and ownership. The PHP files should be readable by the NGINX user (usually `www-data` or `nginx`) and the parent directories should have appropriate permissions as well.

6. Test with a simple PHP file: Create a simple PHP file (e.g., `test.php`) with the following content: `<?php phpinfo(); ?>`. Place this file in the web root directory (usually `/var/www/html`). Access the file in your browser (e.g., `http://localhost/test.php`) and see if it executes properly. If it still downloads, there may be an issue with the PHP installation or configuration.

If none of the above steps resolve the issue, it is recommended to check the NGINX and PHP-FPM error logs for any relevant error messages that can help identify the problem.

title: Prestashop backoffice works but the frontoffice doesn't. The url is not found
text:
I have developed a multilanguage prestashop store completely in localhost using xampp in mac and it works. Both the backoffice and the store (frontoffice). After that, i have deployed it to amazon but there comes my problem. The backoffice works but the store doesn't.

The browser just displays an apache 404 page and tells me The requested URL domain/prestashop/en/ was not found on this server. But it does exist. Besides, the backoffice confirms it.

Inspecting the error.log I find the following message:

[Thu Mar 12 11:12:37 2015] [error] [client xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx] File does not exist: /var/www/prestashop/en

For what I see, Apache is treating the language (/en/) as file when it is not. I've searched all across the web and I can't find how to fix it. I know it is a server issue, but somehow can't find the solution.

What's the matter here?
completion:
There could be several reasons why the front office of your Prestashop website is not working while the back office is functioning properly. Here are a few possible causes and solutions:

1. Incorrect URL or domain configuration: Make sure that the URL of your front office is correctly configured in the Prestashop settings. Check the "Shop URL" configuration in the back office under "Preferences" > "SEO & URLs". Ensure that the domain name, protocol (HTTP or HTTPS), and path are correct.

2. DNS or hosting issues: Verify that your domain name is correctly pointing to the server where your Prestashop website is hosted. Check the DNS settings of your domain and ensure they are correctly configured. Additionally, confirm that your hosting server is properly set up and running without any issues.

3. .htaccess file problems: The .htaccess file in the root directory of your Prestashop installation might be causing the issue. Rename the .htaccess file to something like .htaccess_old and try accessing the front office again. If it works, then the problem lies within the .htaccess file. You can regenerate a new .htaccess file by going to "Preferences" > "SEO & URLs" in the back office and clicking on the "Save" button.

4. Theme or module conflicts: Disable any recently installed themes or modules that might be causing conflicts with the front office. Go to "Modules" > "Modules & Services" in the back office and disable any recently added modules. If the issue is resolved, you can try enabling the modules one by one to identify the conflicting one. Similarly, switch to a default Prestashop theme to check if the problem is related to the current theme.

5. Cache issues: Clear the cache of your Prestashop website. In the back office, go to "Advanced Parameters" > "Performance" and click on the "Clear cache" button. Additionally, you can try disabling the cache temporarily to see if it resolves the issue. Remember to re-enable the cache after testing.

If none of the above solutions work, it might be helpful to check the server logs or contact your hosting provider for further assistance.

2. Insufficient file permissions: Verify that the PHP script has the necessary permissions to access the input file. Ensure that the file permissions allow the PHP script to read the file.

6. File is in a different directory: If the input file is located in a different directory than the PHP script, you may need to provide the full path to the file or navigate to the correct directory before attempting to open the file.

By addressing these potential issues, you should be able to resolve the "Could not open input file" error in your PHP shell script.

title: PHP output buffer not flushing
text:
I have a number of scripts that echo progress as they execute because they are long running. Each basically does the following at the end of each looped row of data processed:

echo '.';
@ob_flush();
flush();

This was working just fine for years and then I upgraded to PHP 5.3.x and Apache 2.2.x across several servers. Now, even if I pad the buffer with white space or set "ob_implicit_flush(1)", I can't get it to show the output on command.

One server still shows the output, but it is in chunks. It can take nearly 5 minutes and then suddenly a string of dots appears on the screen. With the other servers, I get nothing until the script finishes executing entirely.

I've tried looking through the php.ini and httpd.conf files to see if I could figure out what had changed between the different servers, but I'm obviously missing something.

I've also tried disabling mod_deflate in .htaccess for the affected scripts, but that doesn't help either (disabling mod_gzip used to fix the problem right away).

Can someone point me in the right direction with this please? Not being able to monitor script execution in real time is causing all sorts of problems but we can't stay on these older PHP versions any longer.

On an even more peculiar side note, I did try downgrading a server to PHP 5.2.17 but the output buffer problem remained after the downgrade. This makes me suspect it is something relating to the way Apache is handling PHP output since Apache 2 was left in place.
completion:
There could be several reasons why the PHP output buffer is not flushing. Here are a few possible causes and solutions:

1. Output buffering is not enabled: Make sure that output buffering is enabled in your PHP configuration. You can check this by looking for the `output_buffering` directive in your `php.ini` file. If it is set to `Off`, change it to `On` or a specific buffer size (e.g., `4096`).

2. Buffer size is too large: If the buffer size is set to a very large value, it may take a long time for the buffer to fill up and flush. Try reducing the buffer size to a smaller value (e.g., `4096`).

3. Output buffering functions are not used correctly: Ensure that you are using the output buffering functions (`ob_start()`, `ob_flush()`, `ob_end_flush()`, etc.) correctly in your code. For example, make sure that you call `ob_start()` before any output is sent to the browser and call `ob_end_flush()` at the end of your script.

4. PHP script execution time limit: If your PHP script takes a long time to execute, it may exceed the maximum execution time limit set in your PHP configuration. This can prevent the output buffer from flushing. You can increase the `max_execution_time` directive in `php.ini` or use the `set_time_limit()` function in your script to extend the execution time.

5. Server configuration: In some cases, the server configuration may override PHP settings and prevent output buffering from working correctly. Check your server configuration files (e.g., Apache's `httpd.conf` or `.htaccess`) for any directives that may affect output buffering.

If none of these solutions work, it may be helpful to provide more details about your specific code and environment to troubleshoot the issue further.

completion:
In programming, passing by reference means that a reference to a variable is passed to a function or method, allowing the function to modify the original variable directly. On the other hand, passing by value means that a copy of the variable's value is passed to the function, and any modifications made within the function do not affect the original variable.

The statement "Only variables should be passed by reference" is a best practice guideline in many programming languages. It suggests that passing non-variable entities, such as constants or expressions, by reference should be avoided. Instead, these entities should be passed by value.

Passing non-variable entities by reference can lead to unexpected behavior and potential bugs. For example, if a constant is passed by reference and the function attempts to modify it, it may result in a runtime error or undefined behavior. Therefore, it is generally recommended to pass only variables by reference to ensure predictable and maintainable code.

title: Inserting data into a table in WordPress database using WordPress $wpdb
text:
I am starting out plugin development and have followed the tutorials on the WordPress Codex sites. I am now stuck - I have a database called "wp_imlisteningto", where the wp_ was inserted using:

$table_name = $wpdb->prefix . "imlisteningto";

When the plugin is activated.

The database itself has three columns, set up when the plugin is activated:

$sql = "CREATE TABLE $table_name (
id mediumint(9) AUTO_INCREMENT,
album VARCHAR(50),
artist VARCHAR(50),
PRIMARY  KEY (id)
);";

I am trying to insert data (by creating a new row) into this database from a php form.

Within the WordPress admin, I create a new page which has the very simple form:

<form action="/wp-content/plugins/listeningto/formhtml.php" method="post">
Album: <input type="text" name="album" />
Artist: <input type="text" name="artist" />
<input type="submit">
</form>

Which as you can see calls formhtml.php, which is:

<?php
global $wpdb;

$wpdb->insert( $table_name, array( 'album' => $_POST['album'], 'artist' => $_POST['artist'] ), array( '$s', '$s' ) );
?>

When I submit the form, I get an Error 500.0 when running the plugin in Worpdress on IIS7.0, and a "Page Not Found" when running on another web server which runs apache.

If I change formhtml.php to:

<?php

echo $_POST['album'];
echo $_POST['artist'];

?>

Works fine - I get the album and artist that I put in the form. Obviously something I'm doing wrong when inserting the data (in a new row) into the database.

Any thoughts as to what that might be?

UPDATE

Ok, so if I update formhtml.php with this:

<?php
require_once('../../../wp-config.php');
$table_name = $wpdb->prefix . "imlisteningto";
$wpdb->insert( $table_name, array( 'album' => $_POST['album'], 'artist' => $_POST['artist'] ), array( '$s', '$s' ) );
?>

I no longer get an error message, but data still doesn't get put into the database.

UPDATE 2

This worked for me:

<?php
require_once('../../../wp-config.php');
global $wpdb;
$table_name = $wpdb->prefix . "imlisteningto";
$wpdb->insert( $table_name, array( 'album' => $_POST['album'], 'artist' => $_POST['artist'] ) );

as did this:

<?php
require_once('../../../wp-load.php');

$wpdb->insert( $table_name, array( 'album' => $_POST['album'], 'artist' => $_POST['artist'] ) );

title: CodeIgniter default controller in a sub directory not working
text:
My default_controller in the routes configuration is set as "home.php".

I have a sub directory for my controllers, lets call it "folder". So if I visit http://mysite.com/folder/, the default controller "folder/home.php" should be called right?

However for some reason this doesn't work, I get a 404. Visiting http://mysite.com/folder/home or http://mysite.com/folder/home/index works as expected. In addition to this, the default controller works in the root directory (http://mysite.com loads home.php).

Any ideas, has anyone else experienced this? I can't get my head around it - it would appear to be a CI issue but I can't find anybody else having the same problem.

The documentation, from the way I understand it at least, suggests that this should work fine: http://codeigniter.com/user_guide/general/controllers.html#subfolders

Setting the default controller to "folder/home.php" means that http://mysite.com/folder/ works fine as expected. Except for I want the default controller to just be "home.php" - whether in the root or in a sub directory, home.php within that directory should be loaded, as the documentation suggests.

Cheers
completion:
If you have a CodeIgniter application with a default controller in a subdirectory and it's not working, there are a few things you can check:

1. Make sure the subdirectory and controller names are correct: Double-check that the subdirectory and controller names are spelled correctly and match the actual directory and file names on your server.

2. Check the routing configuration: Open the `application/config/routes.php` file and make sure you have set up the correct routing for your subdirectory and default controller. For example, if your subdirectory is called "admin" and your default controller is called "dashboard", you would add the following line to the routes file:

   ```php
   $route['admin'] = 'admin/dashboard';
   ```

   This will route requests to `http://example.com/admin` to the `dashboard` controller in the `admin` subdirectory.

3. Check the controller file: Open the controller file located in the subdirectory and make sure it extends the `CI_Controller` class and has a public method named `index`. For example:

   ```php
   class Dashboard extends CI_Controller {
       public function index() {
           // Your code here
       }
   }
   ```

   The `index` method will be called when the default controller is accessed.

4. Check the .htaccess file: If you are using Apache as your web server, make sure you have an `.htaccess` file in your CodeIgniter root directory with the following content:

   ```
   RewriteEngine on
   RewriteCond $1 !^(index\.php|images|robots\.txt)
   RewriteRule ^(.*)$ /index.php/$1 [L]
   ```

   This will remove the `index.php` from the URL and allow CodeIgniter to handle the routing correctly.

If you have checked all these steps and the default controller in the subdirectory is still not working, there may be an issue with your CodeIgniter installation or server configuration. In that case, you may need to consult the CodeIgniter documentation or seek help from the CodeIgniter community.

title: Laravel : How to take last n(any number) rows after ordered in ascending order?

  2. I also have 5 datas, world => time4, hello => time2,haha => time1,hihio => time5 and dunno => time3 and these datas are arranged in ascending order (as arranged here) based on their id.

In laravel 4, I want to fetch these data, arrange them in ascending order and take the last n(in this case, 3) number of records. So, I want to get dunno,world and hihio rows displayed like this in a div :

dunno,time3
world,time4
hihio,time5

What I have tried

Model::orderBy('created_at','asc')->take(3);

undesired result :

haha,time1
hello,time2
dunno,time3

Also tried

Model::orderBy('created_at','desc')->take(3);

undesired result :

hihio,time5
world,time4
dunno,time3

I have also tried the reverse with no luck

Model::take(3)->orderBy('created_at','asc');

This problem seems fairly simple but I just can't seem to get my logic right. I'm still fairly new in Laravel 4 so I would give bonus points to better solutions than using orderBy() and take() if there is. Thank you very much!
completion:
To take the last n rows after ordering in ascending order in Laravel, you can use the `orderBy` and `take` methods. Here's an example:

```php
$lastRows = YourModel::orderBy('column_name', 'asc')
                ->take($n)
                ->get();
```

Replace `YourModel` with the name of your Eloquent model and `column_name` with the column you want to order by.

The `orderBy` method is used to sort the rows in ascending order based on the specified column. The `take` method is used to limit the number of rows to be retrieved.

You can then access the last n rows using the `$lastRows` variable.

title: Why isn't my PHP SHA256 hash equivalent to C# SHA256Managed hash
text:
Why aren't these the same?

php:

    $hash = hash('sha256', $userData['salt'] . hash('sha256', $password) );

c#

    public static string ComputeHash(string plainText, string salt)
    {
        // Convert plain text into a byte array.
        byte[] plainTextBytes = Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(plainText);
        byte[] saltBytes = Encoding.UTF8.GetBytes(salt);

        SHA256Managed hash = new SHA256Managed();

        // Compute hash value of salt.
        byte[] plainHash = hash.ComputeHash(plainTextBytes);

        byte[] concat = new byte[plainHash.Length + saltBytes.Length];

        System.Buffer.BlockCopy(saltBytes, 0, concat, 0, saltBytes.Length);
        System.Buffer.BlockCopy(plainHash, 0, concat, saltBytes.Length, plainHash.Length);

        byte[] tHashBytes = hash.ComputeHash(concat);

        // Convert result into a base64-encoded string.
        string hashValue = Convert.ToBase64String(tHashBytes);

        // Return the result.
        return hashValue;
    }
completion:
There could be several reasons why your PHP SHA256 hash is not equivalent to the C# SHA256Managed hash. Here are a few possible explanations:

1. Encoding: Make sure you are using the same encoding in both PHP and C#. The encoding can affect the byte representation of the input data, which in turn affects the hash calculation. UTF-8 is a common encoding choice for hashing.

2. Input data: Ensure that you are providing the same input data to both PHP and C#. Even a small difference in the input data can result in completely different hash values.

3. Padding: Check if the padding settings are the same in both PHP and C#. Padding refers to the process of adding extra bits to the input data to ensure it meets the block size requirements of the hashing algorithm. If the padding settings differ, the hash values will also differ.

4. Hash algorithm implementation: Verify that both PHP and C# are using the same implementation of the SHA256 algorithm. While SHA256 is a standard algorithm, different programming languages or libraries may have their own implementations, which can lead to different hash values.

5. Byte order: Ensure that the byte order (little-endian or big-endian) is consistent between PHP and C#. If the byte order is different, the resulting hash values will also be different.

By carefully comparing the code and settings used in both PHP and C#, you should be able to identify the specific reason for the discrepancy in the hash values.

text:
Consider the following piece of JSONPath:

{
   "result":[
      {
         "type":"Residence",
         "street":"Piazza di Spagna",
         "city":"-4:0"
      },
      {
         "type":"Residence",
         "street":"test",
         "city":"-4:1"
      }
   ]
}

Is it possible to get a list of all the node-names?
So for example, I want a list like: type, street, city.
completion:
To get the node names using JSONPath, you can use the `*` wildcard character followed by the `@` symbol. Here's an example:

JSON data:
```json
{
  "name": "John",
  "age": 30,
  "address": {
    "street": "123 Main St",
    "city": "New York"
  },
  "phoneNumbers": [
    "123-456-7890",
    "987-654-3210"
  ]
}
```

JSONPath query to get the node names:
```
$.*.@
```

Output:
```
[
  "name",
  "age",
  "address",
  "phoneNumbers"
]
```

In this example, the `$.*.@` JSONPath query selects all the node names in the JSON data. The `*` wildcard selects all the immediate child nodes of the root node, and the `@` symbol represents the node name.

title: PHP MVC Best Practices/"Rules" for Success
text:
I'm sure that someone already posted this question; however, I would like to get all kind of recommendations for MVC on PHP. I know there are many experts out there willing to share their knowledge with people who has doubts about their coding best practices.

  • How should you organize your Controller?
  • How should you organize your Model?
  • Should Controller call one Model Method and the Model call submethods or should controller call all Model Submethods?
  • etc.

Hope this helps someone out there (because it'll help me for sure).
completion:
1. Follow the separation of concerns principle: Separate your code into distinct layers for Model, View, and Controller. This helps in maintaining code readability, reusability, and scalability.

2. Use a framework: Utilize a PHP MVC framework like Laravel, Symfony, or CodeIgniter. These frameworks provide a structured approach to MVC development and offer built-in features for routing, database handling, and security.

3. Keep your controllers thin: Controllers should only handle the request and delegate the business logic to the model layer. Avoid putting too much code in the controllers to maintain code readability and reusability.

4. Use models for data manipulation: Models should handle data retrieval, manipulation, and storage. Avoid putting any business logic in the views or controllers. Keep the models focused on data-related operations.

5. Use views for presentation logic: Views should only contain presentation logic and should not have any business logic. Use templates or view helpers to separate the presentation from the data.

6. Use routing for clean URLs: Utilize routing to define clean and meaningful URLs for your application. This helps in improving SEO and user experience.

7. Implement validation and sanitization: Validate and sanitize user input to prevent security vulnerabilities and ensure data integrity. Use built-in validation libraries or custom validation methods to handle input validation.

8. Implement caching: Use caching techniques to improve performance and reduce database queries. Cache frequently accessed data or rendered views to minimize server load and response time.

9. Implement error handling and logging: Handle errors gracefully and log them for debugging purposes. Use try-catch blocks to catch exceptions and log error messages to a file or database.

10. Implement security measures: Implement security measures like input validation, output escaping, and user authentication to protect against common security threats like SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and cross-site request forgery (CSRF).

11. Use version control: Utilize a version control system like Git to track changes in your codebase. This helps in collaboration, code review, and rollback to previous versions if needed.

12. Write unit tests: Implement unit tests to ensure the correctness of your code and catch any potential bugs or regressions. Use testing frameworks like PHPUnit to automate the testing process.

13. Follow coding standards: Adhere to coding standards like PSR-12 to maintain code consistency and readability. Use code linters or IDE plugins to enforce coding standards automatically.

14. Document your code: Document your code using inline comments or generate API documentation using tools like PHPDoc. This helps in understanding the codebase and facilitates collaboration with other developers.

15. Optimize performance: Optimize your code for performance by minimizing database queries, using caching techniques, and optimizing resource-intensive operations. Use profiling tools to identify bottlenecks and optimize accordingly.

Remember, these are general best practices, and you may need to adapt them based on your specific project requirements and constraints.

title: array_unique for arrays inside array
text:
I need a function like array_unique for arrays inside array.

The Case - should be equal, but output "not equal":

<?php
$arr=array(array('a',1),array('a',2));
$arr2=array_unique($arr);
if($arr2==$arr){
  echo "equal";
}
else{

}
?>

How should the code be changed to get output "equal"?
completion:
To apply the `array_unique` function to arrays inside an array, you can use a combination of `array_map` and `array_unique`. Here's an example:

```php
$array = [
    [1, 2, 3],
    [2, 3, 4],
    [3, 4, 5]
];

$uniqueArray = array_map('array_unique', $array);

print_r($uniqueArray);
```

Output:
```
Array
(
    [0] => Array
        (
            [0] => 1
            [1] => 2
            [2] => 3
        )
```

In this example, `array_map` is used to apply the `array_unique` function to each sub-array inside the main array. The result is a new array where each sub-array contains only unique values.

completion:
There could be several reasons why cached PHP generated thumbnails are loading slowly. Here are a few possible causes and solutions:

1. Insufficient server resources: Check if your server has enough memory and processing power to handle the thumbnail generation process efficiently. If not, consider upgrading your server or optimizing your code to use fewer resources.

2. Large image sizes: If the original images are large in size, generating thumbnails from them can take longer. Consider resizing the images before generating thumbnails or using a more efficient image processing library.

3. Inefficient caching mechanism: Make sure your caching mechanism is properly implemented and optimized. If the cache is not being utilized effectively, it can slow down the loading of cached thumbnails. Consider using a more efficient caching mechanism or optimizing the existing one.

4. Slow disk I/O: If the server's disk I/O is slow, it can affect the loading speed of cached thumbnails. Consider using a faster storage solution or optimizing the disk I/O operations.

5. Network latency: If the server and client are located far apart or if there are network issues, it can cause slow loading of cached thumbnails. Consider using a content delivery network (CDN) to serve the thumbnails from a location closer to the client.

6. Inefficient code: Review your PHP code for any inefficiencies or bottlenecks. Make sure the thumbnail generation process is optimized and does not contain any unnecessary operations or loops.

7. Database queries: If your PHP code relies on database queries to fetch image data or metadata, slow database queries can impact the thumbnail loading speed. Optimize your database queries or consider caching the necessary data to reduce database access.

8. Server configuration: Check if your server is properly configured for PHP and image processing. Ensure that the necessary extensions and libraries are installed and configured correctly.

By identifying and addressing these potential issues, you should be able to improve the loading speed of cached PHP generated thumbnails.

title: Storing datetime as UTC in PHP/MySQL
text:
Everywhere I read about converting time to a user's timezone says that the best method is to store a date and time in UTC then just add the user's timezone offset to this time.

How can I store a date in UTC time? I use the MySQL DATETIME field.

When adding a new record to MySQL in my PHP code I would use now() to insert into MySQL DATETIME.

Would I need to use something different than now() to store UTC time?
completion:
To store datetime as UTC in PHP/MySQL, you can follow these steps:

1. Set the default timezone in PHP to UTC using the `date_default_timezone_set()` function. This ensures that all datetime operations in PHP are performed in UTC.

```php
date_default_timezone_set('UTC');
```

2. When inserting datetime values into the MySQL database, convert them to UTC using the `gmdate()` function. This function returns the current UTC date and time.

```php
$utcDateTime = gmdate('Y-m-d H:i:s');
```

3. Store the `$utcDateTime` value in the MySQL database.

4. When retrieving datetime values from the MySQL database, convert them back to the local timezone using the `date()` function. This function formats the date and time based on the specified format.

```php
$localDateTime = date('Y-m-d H:i:s', strtotime($utcDateTime));
```

Note: The `strtotime()` function is used to convert the UTC datetime string to a Unix timestamp, which is then passed to the `date()` function for formatting.

By following these steps, you can ensure that datetime values are stored and retrieved in UTC in PHP/MySQL.

title: Default array values if key doesn't exist?
text:
If I have an array full of information, is there any way I can a default for values to be returned if the key doesn't exist?

function items() {
    return array(
        'one' => array(
              'a' => 1,
              'b' => 2,
              'c' => 3,
              'd' => 4,
         ),
         'two' => array(
              'a' => 1,
              'b' => 2,
              'c' => 3,
              'd' => 4,
         ),
         'three' => array(
              'a' => 1,
              'b' => 2,
              'c' => 3,
              'd' => 4,
         ),
    );
}

And in my code

$items = items();
echo $items['one']['a']; // 1

But can I have a default value to be returned if I give a key that doesn't exist like,

$items = items();
echo $items['four']['a']; // DOESN'T EXIST RETURN DEFAULT OF 99
completion:
In most programming languages, if a key doesn't exist in an array, the default value returned depends on the implementation. Here are some common behaviors:

1. Python: If a key doesn't exist in a dictionary (Python's equivalent of an associative array), it raises a `KeyError` exception. However, you can use the `get()` method to specify a default value to be returned if the key is not found.

```python
my_dict = {"key1": "value1", "key2": "value2"}
print(my_dict.get("key3", "default_value"))  # Output: default_value
```

2. JavaScript: If a key doesn't exist in an object (JavaScript's equivalent of an associative array), it returns `undefined`. However, you can use the `||` operator to specify a default value to be returned if the key is not found.

```javascript
const myObj = {key1: "value1", key2: "value2"};
console.log(myObj.key3 || "default_value");  // Output: default_value
```

3. PHP: If a key doesn't exist in an array, it returns `null`. However, you can use the `??` operator to specify a default value to be returned if the key is not found.

```php
$myArray = ["key1" => "value1", "key2" => "value2"];
echo $myArray["key3"] ?? "default_value";  // Output: default_value
```

It's important to note that these behaviors may vary depending on the programming language and its specific implementation.

title: How to render CSRF input in twig?
text: I know there's the usual way to render CSRF token hidden input with form_rest, but is there a way to render just CSRF input itself? I've overridden {% block field_widget %} in theme to render a piece of additional text. But as CSRF token is rendered in input field too and I got a piece of text I don't need next to a hidden field. So I'd like to render it separately with an argument that tells it not to render this text.
completion:
To render a CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) input in Twig, you can use the `{{ csrf_token() }}` function provided by Symfony's Twig extension. Here's an example of how to render a CSRF input in Twig:

```twig
<form action="/submit" method="post">
    {{ csrf_token()|raw }}
    <input type="text" name="username">
    <input type="password" name="password">
    <button type="submit">Submit</button>
</form>
```

In this example, `{{ csrf_token()|raw }}` will generate a hidden input field with the CSRF token value. The `|raw` filter is used to prevent Twig from escaping the HTML output.

Make sure you have the Symfony Twig extension installed and properly configured in your project.

I search on it, and, change the port of Apache in Config -> Service and Port setting. I have;

I also uninstall Skype (Windows 8/10/Metro version). Nothing is working. In the httpd.conf file I have;

I start it via apache_start.bat and get;

(OS 10013)An attempt was made to access a socket in a way forbidden by its access permissions.  : AH00072: make_sock: could not bind to address [::]:445

Please note that all the log files don’t exists! Skype is uninstalled.
completion:
There could be several reasons why XAMPP is unable to start Apache on Windows 10. Here are some possible solutions:

1. Check for conflicting applications: Make sure there are no other applications running on your system that might be using the same port (usually port 80) that Apache requires. Skype, IIS, or other web servers can sometimes cause conflicts. Close any such applications and try starting Apache again.

2. Run XAMPP as an administrator: Right-click on the XAMPP icon and select "Run as administrator." This will ensure that XAMPP has the necessary permissions to start Apache.

3. Check the Apache error log: Open the XAMPP control panel and click on the "Logs" button next to Apache. This will open the Apache error log file. Look for any error messages that might indicate the cause of the problem. Common issues include incorrect configuration settings or missing files.

4. Change the Apache port: If there is a conflict with another application using port 80, you can try changing the port that Apache uses. Open the "httpd.conf" file located in the "conf" folder of your XAMPP installation directory. Look for the line that says "Listen 80" and change it to a different port number (e.g., "Listen 8080"). Save the file and try starting Apache again.

5. Disable Windows Firewall or antivirus software: Sometimes, the Windows Firewall or antivirus software can block Apache from starting. Temporarily disable these security measures and try starting Apache again. If it works, you can then configure your firewall or antivirus software to allow Apache through.

6. Reinstall XAMPP: If none of the above solutions work, you can try reinstalling XAMPP. Make sure to uninstall the existing XAMPP installation completely before reinstalling.

If you are still unable to start Apache after trying these solutions, it might be helpful to seek assistance from the XAMPP community or support forums.

If you are trying to access http://localhost/ on Windows 7 and it is not working, there could be several potential issues:

1. Web server not running: Make sure you have a web server software installed and running on your Windows 7 machine. Common web server software includes Apache, IIS, or XAMPP. Check if the web server service is running properly.

2. Incorrect URL: Double-check that you are entering the correct URL in your web browser. It should be "http://localhost/" without any additional characters or misspellings.

3. Port conflict: If you have multiple web server software installed, there might be a port conflict. By default, web servers usually run on port 80. Check if any other software is using port 80, and if so, either change the port for the conflicting software or the web server.

6. Web server configuration issue: Check the configuration files of your web server software to ensure it is correctly set up to serve content from the localhost.

7. DNS resolution issue: If you are using a custom domain name instead of "localhost," ensure that the domain name is properly resolved to the correct IP address in your DNS settings.

By troubleshooting these potential issues, you should be able to determine the cause of the problem and resolve it.
