   use Faker\Factory as Faker;
   ```

3. Inside the `run()` method of your seed file, create an instance of the Faker generator by adding the following code:
   ```php
   $faker = Faker::create();
   ```

4. Now, when you want to override an argument for a factory, you can use the `$faker` instance. For example, if you have a factory for a `User` model and want to override the `name` attribute, you can do it like this:
   ```php
   factory(User::class)->create([
       'name' => $faker->name,
   ]);
   ```

That's it! You have now declared and can use the `$faker` instance in your seed file to override factory arguments.

title: MongoDb: Benefit of using ObjectID vs a string containing an Id?
text:
Is there any benefit to storing an id to a related document as an ObjectId versus storing it as a string literal?

Using ObjectID:

{
   "_id": ObjectId("522bb79455449d881b004d27"),
   "username": "admin",
   "folder": ObjectId("522bb79455449d881b004d23")
}

versus a string:

{
   "_id": ObjectId("522bb79455449d881b004d27"),
   "username": "admin",
   "folder": "522bb79455449d881b004d23"
}

For my API where I'm sending data back to a client... using the string means I don't have to "cleanup" the data... and as we have to do a second query to get the folder document anyway... is it worth using ObjectId? (and if so why?)

Thanks
completion:
There are several benefits of using ObjectID over a string containing an ID in MongoDB:

1. Uniqueness: ObjectID is designed to be globally unique across different machines and databases. It consists of a timestamp, machine identifier, process identifier, and a random value, ensuring that each generated ID is unique. This eliminates the need for additional logic to ensure uniqueness when using a string ID.

2. Sorting: ObjectID includes a timestamp component, which allows for natural sorting of documents based on their creation time. This can be useful in scenarios where you need to retrieve documents in a specific order, such as retrieving the most recent documents first.

3. Performance: ObjectID is a 12-byte binary value, whereas a string ID can be of variable length. The smaller size of ObjectID can lead to better performance in terms of storage and indexing. It also reduces the network overhead when transferring data between the client and the server.

4. Built-in support: MongoDB provides built-in support for ObjectID, including various methods and operators that can be used for querying and manipulating documents based on their ObjectID values. This makes it easier to work with ObjectID compared to a custom string ID.

5. Security: ObjectID values are harder to guess or predict compared to a string ID, which can be beneficial in scenarios where you want to prevent unauthorized access to certain documents. However, it's important to note that ObjectID alone should not be relied upon for security purposes and additional security measures should be implemented.

Overall, using ObjectID provides several advantages in terms of uniqueness, sorting, performance, built-in support, and security compared to using a string containing an ID in MongoDB.

title: What are the main differences between PHPExcel and PhpSpreadsheet?
text:
In project of PHPOffice there are two projects associated with spreadsheet file formats:

PHPExcel

PHPExcel is a library written in pure PHP and providing a set of classes that allow you to write to and read from different spreadsheet file formats, like Excel (BIFF) .xls, Excel 2007 (OfficeOpenXML) .xlsx, CSV, Libre/OpenOffice Calc .ods, Gnumeric, PDF, HTML, ... This project is built around Microsoft's OpenXML standard and PHP.

and

PhpSpreadsheets

PhpSpreadsheet is a library written in pure PHP and providing a set of classes that allow you to read from and to write to different spreadsheet file formats, like Excel and LibreOffice Calc.

What are the main differences between them?
completion:
PHPExcel and PhpSpreadsheet are both PHP libraries used for reading and writing spreadsheet files, but there are some key differences between them:

1. Development: PHPExcel is the older library and is no longer actively maintained. PhpSpreadsheet is the successor to PHPExcel and is actively developed and maintained.

2. Compatibility: PhpSpreadsheet is compatible with PHP 5.6 and above, while PHPExcel is compatible with PHP 5.2 and above. PhpSpreadsheet also supports newer spreadsheet file formats like XLSX, ODS, and XLSM, whereas PHPExcel has limited support for these formats.

3. Performance: PhpSpreadsheet is generally faster and more memory-efficient compared to PHPExcel. It has been optimized for better performance and reduced memory usage.

4. Features: PhpSpreadsheet includes all the features of PHPExcel and introduces new features and improvements. It provides better support for formulas, charts, conditional formatting, and other advanced spreadsheet functionalities.

5. Documentation: PhpSpreadsheet has more comprehensive and up-to-date documentation compared to PHPExcel. It provides detailed examples and guides for various use cases.

Overall, if you are starting a new project or looking to upgrade an existing one, it is recommended to use PhpSpreadsheet due to its active development, improved performance, and enhanced features.

title: IE10 sharing cookies across subdomains by default
text:
IE10 appears to handle cookies and subdomains differently than other major browsers (IE8, IE9, Firefox, Chrome, Safari).

We use subdomains extensively for test environments, e.g.:

  • user1.devel.example.com
  • user2.devel.example.com
  • qa.example.com

And our production environment lives at the top, e.g. example.com (and technically at www.example.com as well).

We use the php setcookie($name, $value, $expires) function naively (no explicit path or domain is specified) to set a cookie, and then clear cookies (when user logs out) by assigning an empty string to the value. This has always worked fine, and each unique subdomain used their own cookies.

IE10 now "shares" the cookie that was set in the TLD with all subdomains. The initial symptom we observed was that no one could log out of the subdomain. We've observed a few things:

  • Even though it shares the value, no subdomain is able to clear the cookie.
  • When the TLD clears the cookie, it is immediately removed from all subdomains as well.

Has anyone else observed similar behavior to how IE10 stores/applies cookies relative to subdomains? Is there any workaround, other than being explicit about which domain the cookie applies to when sending the initial Set-Cookie header?
completion:
In Internet Explorer 10, cookies are shared across subdomains by default. This means that if a cookie is set for a specific domain, it will be accessible by any subdomain of that domain.

For example, if a cookie is set for "example.com", it will be accessible by "subdomain.example.com" as well as any other subdomains of "example.com".

This behavior can be useful in certain scenarios where you want to share user authentication or session information across multiple subdomains. However, it can also pose a security risk if sensitive information is stored in cookies and accessed by unauthorized subdomains.

To prevent cookies from being shared across subdomains in Internet Explorer 10, you can set the "domain" attribute of the cookie to the specific subdomain you want it to be accessible from. This will restrict the cookie to that subdomain only and prevent it from being accessed by other subdomains.

Overall, it is important to be aware of the default behavior of cookie sharing in Internet Explorer 10 and take appropriate measures to ensure the security of your website's cookies.

title: Is there a way to sync settings across JetBrains IDEs?
text:
What is the best way to sync similar settings across JetBrains IDEs? For example I have PyCharm and PhpStorm, both of which support CSS and HTML, and I would like to have all of the syntax coloring, inspections, etc. be the same for both PyCharm and PhpStorm. completion:
Yes, JetBrains provides a feature called "Settings Sync" that allows you to synchronize your IDE settings across different JetBrains IDEs. This feature is available in IntelliJ IDEA, PyCharm, WebStorm, PhpStorm, and other JetBrains IDEs.

To use Settings Sync, you need to have a JetBrains account and be logged in to your IDE with that account. Then, you can go to the "File" menu, select "Manage IDE Settings," and choose "Sync Settings." This will open the Settings Sync dialog.

In the Settings Sync dialog, you can enable synchronization and choose the settings you want to sync, such as keymaps, color schemes, code style settings, and more. You can also specify which plugins and their settings should be synchronized.

Once you have configured the settings you want to sync, you can click on the "Sync Now" button to upload your settings to the JetBrains servers. After that, you can sign in to another JetBrains IDE with the same account and use the "Sync Settings" feature to download and apply your synchronized settings.

Settings Sync also allows you to share your settings with others by generating a shareable link. This can be useful if you want to share your settings with teammates or colleagues.

Note that Settings Sync requires an active internet connection to synchronize your settings.

title: Error #1044 - Access denied for user 'root'@'localhost' to database 'information_schema'
text:
Alright, so here is the scenario

I performed a full backup on my mysql server today. Now when I try to import that .sql dump file, I get the error mentioned in the title and it does not load all the other databases.

How can I get around this so phymyadmin will allow me to import the whole file, or is there a way I could "remove" information_schema from the sql dump

Thanks
completion:
Error #1044 occurs when the user 'root'@'localhost' does not have the necessary privileges to access the 'information_schema' database.

The 'information_schema' database is a system database that contains metadata about other databases in the MySQL server. It is not meant to be accessed or modified directly by users.

To resolve this error, you can try the following steps:

1. Check if you are using the correct username and password for the MySQL server. The default username for MySQL is 'root', but it is possible that you have a different username or that the password is incorrect.

2. Make sure that the user 'root'@'localhost' has the necessary privileges to access the 'information_schema' database. You can do this by logging in to MySQL as the root user and running the following command:

   GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON information_schema.* TO 'root'@'localhost';

   This command grants all privileges to the 'root' user for the 'information_schema' database.

3. If you are still unable to access the 'information_schema' database, it is possible that your MySQL installation has been misconfigured or that there are other issues with your MySQL server. In this case, you may need to consult the MySQL documentation or seek assistance from a database administrator or technical support.

title: How to use PHP Composer on HostGator
text:
I recently decided to start a project in Zend Framework 2 and was having trouble getting it to run on a HostGator shared server.

By default, HostGator's shared servers run in PHP 5.2.2 and if you upload the ZF2 Skeleton Application, it will not run out of the box.

Also, if you happen to have SSH access to your HG Shared account (You usually have to request it), you won't be able to run .PHAR files because the CLI version of PHP is also 5.2.2.

Luckily, I got it to work... see below.
completion:
To use PHP Composer on HostGator, you can follow these steps:

1. Log in to your HostGator cPanel account.
2. Navigate to the "File Manager" section.
3. Open the root directory of your website (usually public_html or www).
4. Create a new file called "composer.json" in the root directory.
5. Edit the "composer.json" file and define the dependencies you want to install. For example:

```json
{
    "require": {
        "monolog/monolog": "^2.0"
    }
}
```

This example specifies that you want to install the Monolog library.

6. Save the "composer.json" file.
7. Go back to the cPanel dashboard and find the "Software" section.
8. Click on "PHP Selector" or "Select PHP Version" (depending on your HostGator version).
9. Make sure you have PHP version 5.3 or higher selected.
10. Enable the "php_openssl" extension if it's not already enabled.
11. Go back to the root directory of your website in the File Manager.
12. Create a new file called "composer.phar" in the root directory.
13. Open the "composer.phar" file and paste the following code:

```php
<?php

Phar::mapPhar('composer.phar');

require_once 'phar://composer.phar/vendor/autoload.php';

__HALT_COMPILER();
```

14. Save the "composer.phar" file.
15. Go to the command line interface (CLI) section of your cPanel.
16. Navigate to the root directory of your website using the "cd" command. For example:

```
cd public_html
```

17. Run the following command to install the dependencies specified in the "composer.json" file:

```
php composer.phar install
```

18. Composer will download and install the required dependencies into a "vendor" directory in your root directory.

You have now successfully used PHP Composer on HostGator. You can include the installed dependencies in your PHP code by requiring the autoload file generated by Composer. For example:

```php
require 'vendor/autoload.php';

// Use the installed libraries here
```

Note: HostGator shared hosting plans may have limitations on the execution time and memory available for PHP scripts. If you encounter any issues during the installation or execution of Composer, you may need to contact HostGator support for assistance.

title: Stacking Multiple Ternary Operators in PHP
text:
This is what I wrote :

 $Myprovince = (
($province == 6) ? "city-1" :
($province == 7) ? "city-2" :
($province == 8) ? "city-3" :
($province == 30) ? "city-4" : "out of borders"
);

But for every field I got the value city-4. I want to use ternary operators instead of switch/if because I want to experiment and see how it would be done.

What's the problem with this code?
completion:
In PHP, you can stack multiple ternary operators to create more complex conditional expressions. The syntax for a ternary operator is:

```php
(condition) ? (value if true) : (value if false);
```

To stack multiple ternary operators, you can use them as the values for the true and false parts of another ternary operator. Here's an example:

```php
$result = ($condition1) ? ($value1) : (($condition2) ? ($value2) : ($value3));
```

In this example, if `condition1` is true, the value of `$result` will be `$value1`. If `condition1` is false, it will check `condition2`. If `condition2` is true, the value of `$result` will be `$value2`. If both `condition1` and `condition2` are false, the value of `$result` will be `$value3`.

You can continue stacking ternary operators as needed to create more complex conditional expressions. However, it's important to note that stacking too many ternary operators can make the code harder to read and understand. It's generally recommended to use if-else statements for more complex conditions to improve code readability.

My Symfony controller code, config, and parameters -

Relevant controller code:

    $data = $form->getData();

    $this->addFlash('success', 'Message sent successfully');

config.yml:

What am I doing wrong?
completion:
In Symfony 3.3, you can use Swiftmailer to send emails from your controller. However, if you want to defer the sending of the email to the server, you can use the `spool` feature of Swiftmailer.

Here's how you can do it:

1. First, make sure you have Swiftmailer installed in your Symfony project. You can install it using Composer:

```
composer require symfony/swiftmailer-bundle
```

2. Configure Swiftmailer in your `config.yml` file:

```yaml
# app/config/config.yml

swiftmailer:
    transport: smtp
    spool:
        type: file
        path: "%kernel.root_dir%/spool"
```

This configuration tells Swiftmailer to use the `smtp` transport and store the emails in a spool file located in the `spool` directory of your Symfony project.

3. In your controller, create a new instance of the `Swift_Message` class and set the necessary details like the sender, recipient, subject, and body of the email:

```php
// src/AppBundle/Controller/DefaultController.php

use Symfony\Bundle\FrameworkBundle\Controller\Controller;
use Symfony\Component\HttpFoundation\Response;

class DefaultController extends Controller
{
    public function sendEmailAction()
    {
        $message = (new \Swift_Message('Hello Email'))
            ->setFrom('sender@example.com')
            ->setTo('recipient@example.com')
            ->setBody(
                $this->renderView(
                    'emails/email.html.twig',
                    array('name' => 'John Doe')
                ),
                'text/html'
            );

        $this->get('mailer')->send($message);

        return new Response('Email sent!');
    }
}
```

4. Finally, you need to configure a cron job to process the spool and send the emails. Add the following command to your crontab file:

```
* * * * * php /path/to/your/symfony/project/bin/console swiftmailer:spool:send --env=prod
```

This cron job will run every minute and send any emails in the spool.

That's it! Now, when you call the `sendEmailAction` method in your controller, the email will be created and added to the spool. The cron job will then send the email from the spool at the next scheduled run.

title: Difference between require, include, require_once and include_once?
text:
In PHP:

  • When should I use require vs. include?
  • When should I use require_once vs. include_once?
completion:
require and include are both used to include and evaluate the specified file in the current script. The main difference between them is how they handle errors:

1. require: If the specified file is not found or cannot be included, require will produce a fatal error and stop the script execution.

2. include: If the specified file is not found or cannot be included, include will produce a warning and continue the script execution.

require_once and include_once are similar to require and include, respectively, but they have an additional check to ensure that the file has not been included before. This prevents multiple inclusions of the same file, which can cause errors or conflicts.

The main differences between require/include and require_once/include_once are:

1. require_once/include_once: These statements will only include the file if it has not been included before. If the file has already been included, they will not include it again.

2. require/include: These statements will include the file every time they are encountered, regardless of whether it has been included before or not.

In summary, require and include are used to include and evaluate files, with require being more strict and producing a fatal error if the file is not found. require_once and include_once are used to include files only if they have not been included before, preventing multiple inclusions.

To resolve this issue, you need to make sure that the mcrypt extension is installed and enabled in your PHP installation. The mcrypt extension provides the necessary functions and constants for encryption and decryption.

Here are the steps to enable the mcrypt extension:

1. Check if the mcrypt extension is installed by running the following command in your terminal or command prompt:
   ```
   php -m | grep mcrypt
   ```

   If the mcrypt extension is installed, it will display "mcrypt" in the output. If it's not installed, you need to install it.

2. Install the mcrypt extension based on your operating system and PHP version. For example, if you are using Ubuntu and PHP 7.4, you can install it by running the following command:
   ```
   sudo apt-get install php7.4-mcrypt
   ```

   Replace "7.4" with your PHP version if you are using a different version.

3. After installing the mcrypt extension, you need to enable it in your PHP configuration. Open the php.ini file and search for the following line:
   ```
   ;extension=mcrypt
   ```

   Remove the semicolon (;) at the beginning of the line to uncomment it:
   ```
   extension=mcrypt
   ```

4. Save the php.ini file and restart your web server for the changes to take effect.

After enabling the mcrypt extension, the MCRYPT_BLOWFISH constant should be defined and you should be able to use it in your code without any errors.

$request->validate([

title: Forcing http using .htaccess
text:
This is the script I have right now, how do I have my script force all traffic to http, currently it is doing the exact opposite, it is forcing all traffic to https. 

RewriteEngine On
RewriteCond %{HTTPS} !=on
RewriteRule ^ https://%{HTTP_HOST}%{REQUEST_URI} [L,R=301]

I've also tried this and it didn't work

RewriteEngine On
RewriteCond %{HTTP} !=on
RewriteRule ^ http://%{HTTP_HOST}%{REQUEST_URI} [L,R=301]

I got this error:

Too many redirects occurred trying to open www.blankpage.com .
completion:
To force HTTP using .htaccess, you can add the following code to your .htaccess file:

```
RewriteEngine On
RewriteCond %{HTTPS} !=on
RewriteRule ^(.*)$ http://%{HTTP_HOST}%{REQUEST_URI} [L,R=301]
```

This code uses mod_rewrite to check if the HTTPS variable is not "on" (meaning the current request is not using HTTPS). If it's not, it redirects the request to the same URL but with "http://" instead of "https://". The [L,R=301] flags indicate that it's a permanent redirect (301) and the rewriting should stop (L) after this rule.

Make sure to place this code at the beginning of your .htaccess file, before any other rules or directives.

completion:

$array = array(

);

key3

title: When do/should I use __construct(), __get(), __set(), and __call() in PHP?
text:
A similar question discusses __construct, but I left it in my title for people searching who find this one.

Apparently, __get and __set take a parameter that is the variable being gotten or set. However, you have to know the variable name (eg, know that the age of the person is $age instead of $myAge). So I don't see the point if you HAVE to know a variable name, especially if you are working with code that you aren't familiar with (such as a library).

completion:
In PHP, you should use the following magic methods in specific scenarios:

1. __construct(): This method is used as a constructor and is automatically called when an object is created from a class. It is used to initialize object properties or perform any necessary setup tasks.

2. __get(): This method is called when an inaccessible or non-existent property is accessed using the object's property syntax. It allows you to define custom logic to retrieve the value of the property dynamically.

3. __set(): This method is called when an inaccessible or non-existent property is assigned a value using the object's property syntax. It allows you to define custom logic to set the value of the property dynamically.

4. __call(): This method is called when an inaccessible or non-existent method is invoked on an object. It allows you to define custom logic to handle method calls dynamically.

You should use these magic methods when you need to implement custom behavior for object initialization, property access, property assignment, or method invocation. They provide flexibility and allow you to define custom logic based on your specific requirements.

5. Page size: The size of the TCPDF page may affect how the image is displayed. If the page size is smaller than the image dimensions, the image may be scaled down to fit within the page boundaries.

6. Margins and padding: Check if there are any margins or padding applied to the image container or the TCPDF page. These can reduce the available space for the image and make it appear smaller.

7. Code errors: Double-check your code to ensure there are no errors or typos that may be affecting the image size. Review the TCPDF documentation and examples to ensure you are using the correct methods and parameters for image rendering.

title: How should I choose an authentication library for CodeIgniter?
text: I see there are a few. Which ones are maintained and easy to use? What are their pros and cons?
completion:
When choosing an authentication library for CodeIgniter, there are several factors to consider. Here are some guidelines to help you make the right choice:

1. Security: Security should be your top priority when selecting an authentication library. Look for libraries that have built-in protection against common security vulnerabilities like SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and cross-site request forgery (CSRF). Check if the library follows best practices for password hashing and storage.

2. Compatibility: Ensure that the authentication library is compatible with the version of CodeIgniter you are using. Check if it supports the necessary PHP version and any other dependencies.

3. Documentation and Community Support: Look for libraries that have comprehensive documentation and an active community. Good documentation will make it easier for you to understand and implement the library, while an active community can provide support and help troubleshoot any issues you may encounter.

4. Features: Consider the features you require for your authentication system. Some common features to look for include user registration, login, logout, password reset, role-based access control, and social media integration. Choose a library that provides the necessary features for your application.

5. Performance: Evaluate the performance of the authentication library. Look for libraries that are optimized for speed and efficiency, as slow authentication processes can impact the overall performance of your application.

6. Customizability: Consider how customizable the authentication library is. Look for libraries that allow you to easily customize the authentication process to fit your specific requirements. This could include customizing the user model, views, and controllers.

7. Reputation and Reviews: Research the reputation of the authentication library and read reviews from other developers who have used it. Look for libraries that have a good reputation and positive reviews, as this indicates that they are reliable and well-regarded within the developer community.

8. Licensing: Check the licensing terms of the authentication library to ensure it aligns with your project's requirements. Some libraries may be open-source and free to use, while others may have commercial licenses or specific usage restrictions.

By considering these factors, you can make an informed decision and choose an authentication library for CodeIgniter that meets your security, compatibility, and functionality needs.

title: How to control json_encode behavior?
text:
Is there any way to control json_encode behavior on objects? Like excluding empty arrays, null fields and so on?

I mean something like when using serialize(), where you can implement magic __sleep() method and specify what properties should be serialized:

class MyClass
{
   public $yes   = "I should be encoded/serialized!";
   public $empty = array(); // // Do not encode me!
   public $null  = null; // Do not encode me!

   public function __sleep() { return array('yes'); }
}

$obj = new MyClass();
var_dump(json_encode($obj));
completion:
To control the behavior of `json_encode()` function in PHP, you can use the optional parameters provided by the function. Here are some ways to control the behavior:

1. Encoding Options:
   - `JSON_FORCE_OBJECT`: By default, `json_encode()` converts arrays into JSON arrays. To force it to convert arrays into JSON objects, you can use the `JSON_FORCE_OBJECT` option.
   Example: `json_encode($data, JSON_FORCE_OBJECT)`

   - `JSON_NUMERIC_CHECK`: By default, `json_encode()` treats numeric strings as strings. To convert numeric strings to actual numbers, you can use the `JSON_NUMERIC_CHECK` option.
   Example: `json_encode($data, JSON_NUMERIC_CHECK)`

   - `JSON_PRETTY_PRINT`: This option formats the JSON output with indentation and line breaks, making it more human-readable.
   Example: `json_encode($data, JSON_PRETTY_PRINT)`

2. Encoding Depth:
   - `JSON_UNESCAPED_UNICODE`: By default, `json_encode()` escapes Unicode characters in the output. To output Unicode characters as they are, you can use the `JSON_UNESCAPED_UNICODE` option.
   Example: `json_encode($data, JSON_UNESCAPED_UNICODE)`

   - `JSON_UNESCAPED_SLASHES`: By default, `json_encode()` escapes forward slashes (/) in the output. To output forward slashes as they are, you can use the `JSON_UNESCAPED_SLASHES` option.
   Example: `json_encode($data, JSON_UNESCAPED_SLASHES)`

3. Error Handling:
   - `JSON_THROW_ON_ERROR`: By default, `json_encode()` returns `false` on error. To throw an exception instead, you can use the `JSON_THROW_ON_ERROR` option.
   Example: `json_encode($data, JSON_THROW_ON_ERROR)`

These options can be combined using the bitwise OR operator (`|`) to achieve the desired behavior. For example:
`json_encode($data, JSON_PRETTY_PRINT | JSON_UNESCAPED_UNICODE)`

Note: The available options may vary depending on the PHP version.

To debug PHP with VSCode and Docker, you can follow these steps:

1. Install the PHP Debug extension in VSCode. You can do this by going to the Extensions view (Ctrl+Shift+X) and searching for "PHP Debug". Click on the extension and click Install.

2. Create a `launch.json` file in your project's `.vscode` directory. This file will contain the configuration for debugging PHP.

environment:

6. Set breakpoints in your PHP code by clicking on the left gutter of the editor where you want the breakpoint to be.

7. Trigger the code execution that you want to debug, either by making a request to your PHP application or by running a command that executes PHP code.

8. VSCode will pause execution at the breakpoints, allowing you to inspect variables, step through the code, and debug your PHP application.

title: Laravel 4 - Child constructor call parent constructor with dependency injection
text:
I'm building a CMS using Laravel 4 and I have a base admin controller for the admin pages that looks something like this:

class AdminController extends BaseController {

    public function __construct(UserAuthInterface $auth, MessagesInterface $message, ModuleManagerInterface $module)
    {
        $this->auth = $auth;
        $this->user = $this->auth->adminLoggedIn();
        $this->message = $message;
        $this->module = $module;
    }
}

Im using Laravel's IOC container to inject the class dependencies into the constructor. I then have various controller classes that control the different modules that make up the CMS and each class extends the admin class. For example:

class UsersController extends AdminController {

    public function home()
    {
        if (!$this->user)
        {
            return Redirect::route('admin.login');
        }
        $messages = $this->message->getMessages();
        return View::make('users::home', compact('messages'));
    }
}

Now this works perfectly however my problem, which is less of a problem and more of a efficiency issue, occurs when I add a constructor to the UsersController class. For example:

class UsersController extends AdminController {

    public function __construct(UsersManager $user)
    {
        $this->users = $users;
    }

    public function home()
    {
        if (!$this->user)
        {
        return Redirect::route('admin.login');
        }
        $messages = $this->message->getMessages();
        return View::make('users::home', compact('messages'));
    }
}

Since the child class now has a constructor it means the parent's constructor isn't getting called and thus things the child class is dependant on, such as this->user are no longer valid, causing errors. I can call the admin controller's construct function via parent::__construct() however since I need to pass it the class dependencies I need to set these dependencies in the child constructor resulting in something that looks like this:

class UsersController extends AdminController {

    public function __construct(UsersManager $user, UserAuthInterface $auth, MessagesInterface $message, ModuleManagerInterface $module)
    {
        parent::__construct($auth, $messages, $module);
        $this->users = $users;
    }

    // Same as before
}

Now this works fine in terms of its functionality; however it doesn't seem very efficient to me to have to include the parent's dependencies in every child class that has a constructor. It also looks quite messy. Does Laravel provide a way around this, or does PHP support a way of calling both the parent and child constructor without having to call parent::__construct() from the child?

I know this is a long question for what is effectively not a problem but more me just be ocd about efficiency, but I appreciate any ideas and/or solutions.

Thanks in advance!

title: Laravel Eloquent where field is X or null
text:
I have a table like this:

table

Now I want to get all entries where field1 is 1, field2 is null and where datefield is smaller than X or null. I already tried something like this:

$query = Model::where('field1', 1)
            ->whereNull('field2')
            ->where('datefield', '<', $date)
            ->orWhereNull('datefield');

but thats not working. I always get every entry where datefield is null. It doesn't matter what the other fields are. I also tried to split it in 2 queries: First get every row where datefield is smaller than X or null and then (based on it) get every field where field1 is 1 and field2 is null.

The result was the same. Any idea how to do this?
completion:
To query records where a specific field is either equal to a certain value or null using Laravel Eloquent, you can use the `orWhereNull` method along with the `where` method. Here's an example:

```php
$records = YourModel::where('field', 'X')
                    ->orWhereNull('field')
                    ->get();
```

In the above example, replace `YourModel` with the actual name of your Eloquent model, and `field` with the name of the field you want to query.

This query will retrieve all records where the `field` is equal to 'X' or null.

title: Which is better approach between fsockopen and curl?
text:
I am creating an app for Automated Recurring Billing.
Please let me know which option should I opt for sending the request to server

  • fsockeopen
  • curl

and why one is better than another?
completion:
The choice between fsockopen and curl depends on the specific use case and requirements. Here are some factors to consider:

1. Simplicity: fsockopen is a lower-level function that provides basic socket communication capabilities. It requires manual handling of HTTP headers, request/response parsing, and error handling. On the other hand, curl is a higher-level library that abstracts away many of these complexities, providing a more user-friendly interface.

2. Features: curl offers a wide range of features and options, including support for various protocols (HTTP, FTP, SMTP, etc.), SSL/TLS encryption, authentication, cookies, proxies, and more. fsockopen, being a lower-level function, provides a more basic level of functionality and may require additional code to implement some of these features.

3. Performance: In terms of performance, fsockopen is generally faster and more lightweight compared to curl. This can be advantageous in scenarios where speed and efficiency are critical, such as high-traffic applications or when making numerous concurrent requests.

4. Compatibility: fsockopen is a built-in PHP function and is available in all PHP installations. On the other hand, curl is an extension that may need to be installed separately, although it is commonly available in most PHP setups.

In summary, if you require a simple and lightweight solution, fsockopen may be sufficient. However, if you need advanced features, ease of use, and better compatibility, curl is generally the preferred choice.

title: How to add 5 minutes to current datetime on php < 5.3
text:
I want to add 5 minutes to this date: 2011-04-8 08:29:49 

$date = '2011-04-8 08:29:49';

When I use strtotime I am always getting 1970-01-01 08:33:31

How do I add correctly 5 minutes to 2011-04-8 08:29:49?
completion:
To add 5 minutes to the current datetime in PHP versions below 5.3, you can use the `strtotime()` function along with the `date()` function. Here's an example:

```php
$currentDateTime = date('Y-m-d H:i:s'); // Get the current datetime
$newDateTime = date('Y-m-d H:i:s', strtotime($currentDateTime) + (5 * 60)); // Add 5 minutes (5 * 60 seconds) to the current datetime

echo $newDateTime; // Output the new datetime
```

In this example, `strtotime()` is used to convert the current datetime into a Unix timestamp. Then, 5 minutes (5 * 60 seconds) are added to the timestamp. Finally, `date()` is used to convert the new timestamp back into a formatted datetime string.

title: knowing when to call persist
text:
I'm using Doctrine 2 as my ORM, and things are going well, but I've been wondering about the EntityManager#persist() method. The "Persisting entities" documentation says the following about a call to persist() for object X:

If X is a preexisting managed entity, it is ignored by the persist operation.

That leads me to believe that persist() need only be called when the object is new and has not yet been saved to the database. However, the documentation for the "Deferred Explicit" change tracking policy says:

... Doctrine 2 only considers entities that have been explicitly marked for change detection through a call to EntityManager#persist(entity) ...

... which sounds like persist() must be called on the object for it to be updated at all. When should persist() be called? If only on new objects, is there a significance performance hit to call it anyway whenever an entity is updated and let Doctrine sort out the difference?
completion:
Knowing when to call persist depends on the specific context and requirements of the situation. Generally, persisting data is necessary when you want to store information for future use or to ensure data integrity. Here are a few scenarios where calling persist might be appropriate:

1. Saving user input: If you have a form or application that collects user input, you would typically call persist to store that data in a database or file system. This ensures that the data is not lost when the application is closed or restarted.

2. Updating database records: When you make changes to a database, such as inserting, updating, or deleting records, calling persist ensures that the changes are permanently saved. This is important for maintaining data consistency and integrity.

3. Caching data: In some cases, you might want to cache data in memory for performance reasons. However, if the data needs to be persisted beyond the current session or application restart, you would call persist to store it in a more permanent storage medium.

4. Logging events or errors: If you need to keep a record of events or errors that occur during the execution of your program, calling persist allows you to store this information for later analysis or debugging.

It's important to consider the trade-offs of persisting data, such as the impact on performance, storage requirements, and data security. In some cases, you might choose not to persist data if it's not necessary or if it can be easily regenerated.

title: Laravel 5.1 Unknown database type enum requested
text:

Unknown database type enum requested, Doctrine\DBAL\Platforms\MySqlPlatform may not support it.

completion:
The error "Unknown database type enum requested" in Laravel 5.1 occurs when you try to use the `enum` column type in your database schema, but the database driver you are using does not support it.

In Laravel 5.1, the `enum` column type is not supported by default in all database drivers. It is only supported by the MySQL and PostgreSQL drivers.

To fix this issue, you have a few options:

1. Change the column type: If possible, you can change the column type from `enum` to a supported type, such as `string` or `integer`.

2. Use a different database driver: If you are not using MySQL or PostgreSQL, you can switch to one of these drivers to use the `enum` column type.

3. Use a package: There are some third-party packages available that add support for the `enum` column type in Laravel 5.1 for other database drivers. You can search for these packages on platforms like Packagist and GitHub.

4. Upgrade Laravel version: Laravel 5.1 is quite old, and newer versions of Laravel have better support for different column types. Consider upgrading to a newer version of Laravel if possible.

Remember to make any necessary changes to your code and database schema after implementing one of these solutions.

title: Why does ltrim remove one character when the second argument contains an operator sign?
text:
If I do:

ltrim('53-34567', '53-');
ltrim('53+34567', '53+');
ltrim('53*34567', '53*');

I get 4567 as the result and not 34567. What's the explanation for this behavior?
completion:
The `ltrim` function in most programming languages is used to remove leading characters from a string. The second argument of `ltrim` specifies the characters to be removed from the beginning of the string.

When the second argument of `ltrim` contains an operator sign, such as `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, etc., it is interpreted as a character range rather than a single character. In most character ranges, the operator sign represents a range of characters between two specified characters.

For example, if the second argument of `ltrim` is `"+-"`, it means that all characters between `+` and `-` (inclusive) will be removed from the beginning of the string. This includes the `+` and `-` characters themselves.

Therefore, when the second argument of `ltrim` contains an operator sign, it is treated as a character range and not as a single character to be removed. This is why `ltrim` removes one character when the second argument contains an operator sign.

title: Sessions in token based authentication
text:
I am building an app in PHP Lumen which returns a token upon login. I am not sure how to proceed beyond this.

How am I supposed to maintain a session using these tokens?

Specifically, how do I store the tokens on the client side if I am using reactjs or vanilla HTML/CSS/jQuery and send them in every request I make for the secure part of my web app?
completion:
In token-based authentication, a session is typically not maintained on the server-side. Instead, a token is generated and sent to the client upon successful authentication. This token is then included in subsequent requests to authenticate the client.

Here are the steps involved in token-based authentication:

1. User provides their credentials (e.g., username and password) to the server.
2. The server verifies the credentials and generates a token.
3. The token is sent back to the client.
4. The client stores the token (usually in local storage or a cookie) for future use.
5. The client includes the token in the header or body of each subsequent request to the server.
6. The server validates the token on each request to ensure the client is authenticated.
7. If the token is valid, the server processes the request and returns the requested data.
8. If the token is invalid or expired, the server returns an error response, and the client may need to re-authenticate.

Since the server does not maintain session state, token-based authentication is often considered stateless. This approach offers several advantages, including scalability, as the server does not need to store session information for each client. Additionally, token-based authentication is commonly used in distributed systems and APIs, where multiple servers may handle requests from the same client.

It's important to note that token-based authentication does not completely eliminate the need for sessions. While the server does not maintain session state, the token itself can be considered a form of session identifier. The token is used to associate subsequent requests with the authenticated user, allowing the server to authorize and process the requests accordingly.

title: Uploading big files over HTTP
text: I need to upload potentially big (as in, 10's to 100's of megabytes) files from a desktop application to a server. The server code is written in PHP, the desktop application in C++/MFC. I want to be able to resume file uploads when the upload fails halfway through because this software will be used over unreliable connections. What are my options? I've found a number of HTTP upload components for C++, such as http://www.chilkatsoft.com/refdoc/vcCkUploadRef.html which looks excellent, but it doesn't seem to handle 'resume' of half done uploads (I assume this is because HTTP 1.1 doesn't support it). I've also looked at the BITS service but for uploads it requires an IIS server. So far my only option seems to be to cut up the file I want to upload into smaller pieces (say 1 meg each), upload them all to the server, reassemble them with PHP and run a checksum to see if everything went ok. To resume, I'd need to have some form of 'handshake' at the beginning of the upload to find out which pieces are already on the server. Will I have to code this by hand or does anyone know of a library that does all this for me, or maybe even a completely different solution? I'd rather not switch to another protocol that supports resume natively for maintenance reasons (potential problems with firewalls etc.)
completion:
Uploading big files over HTTP can be challenging due to limitations in the HTTP protocol and server configurations. Here are a few approaches to handle this:

1. Chunked Transfer Encoding: Use chunked transfer encoding to split the file into smaller chunks and send them sequentially. This allows the server to process each chunk individually, reducing memory usage. The client can send each chunk with the appropriate headers indicating the chunk size.

2. Multipart Upload: Split the file into multiple parts and send them as separate parts in a multipart request. Each part can be sent with its own headers and boundaries. This approach is commonly used in HTML forms with file uploads.

3. Resumable Uploads: Implement resumable uploads to handle interruptions or failures during the upload process. This involves dividing the file into smaller chunks and sending them individually. If an interruption occurs, the client can resume the upload from the last successfully uploaded chunk.

4. Compression: Compress the file before uploading to reduce its size. This can be done using algorithms like gzip or deflate. However, keep in mind that the server must support decompression to handle the uploaded file correctly.

5. Use a Dedicated File Transfer Protocol: If HTTP is not suitable for your requirements, consider using a dedicated file transfer protocol like FTP or SFTP. These protocols are specifically designed for transferring large files and offer features like resumable uploads, compression, and better performance.

It's important to note that the server configuration may also impose limitations on file uploads, such as maximum file size or timeout settings. Make sure to check and adjust these settings accordingly.

title: What's the net::ERR_HTTP2_PROTOCOL_ERROR about?
text:
I'm currently working on a website, which triggers a net::ERR_HTTP2_PROTOCOL_ERROR 200 error on Google Chrome. I'm not sure exactly what can provoke this error, I just noticed it pops out only when accessing the website in HTTPS. I can't be 100% sure it is related, but it looks like it prevents JavaScript to be executed properly.

For instance, the following scenario happens :

  1. I'm accessing the website in HTTPS

  2. My Twitter feed integrated via https://publish.twitter.com isn't loaded at all

  3. I can notice in the console the ERR_HTTP2_PROTOCOL_ERROR

  4. If I remove the code to load the Twitter feed, the error remains

  5. If I access the website in HTTP, the Twitter feed appears and the error disappears

Google Chrome is the only web browser triggering the error: it works well on both Edge and Firefox. (NB: I tried with Safari, and I have a similar kcferrordomaincfnetwork 303 error)

I was wondering if it could be related to the header returned by the server since there is this '200' mention in the error, and a 404 / 500 page isn't triggering anything.

Thing is the error isn't documented at all. Google search gives me very few results. Moreover, I noticed it appears on very recent Google Chrome releases; the error doesn't pop on v.64.X, but it does on v.75+ (regardless of the OS; I'm working on Mac tho).

Might be related to Website OK on Firefox but not on Safari (kCFErrorDomainCFNetwork error 303) neither Chrome (net::ERR_SPDY_PROTOCOL_ERROR)

Findings from further investigations are the following:

  • error doesn't pop on the exact same page if server returns 404 instead of 2XX
  • error doesn't pop on local with a HTTPS certificate
  • error pops on a different server (both are OVH's), which uses a different certificate
  • error pops no matter what PHP version is used, from 5.6 to 7.3 (framework used : Cakephp 2.10)

As requested, below is the returned header for the failing ressource, which is the whole web page. Even if the error is triggering on each page having a HTTP header 200, those pages are always loading on client's browser, but sometimes an element is missing (in my exemple, the external Twitter feed). Every other asset on the Network tab has a success return, except the whole document itself.

Google Chrome header (with error):

Firefox header (without error):

A curl --head --http2 request in console returns the following success:

HTTP/2 200 
date: Fri, 04 Oct 2019 08:04:51 GMT
content-type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
content-length: 127089
set-cookie: SERVERID31396=2341116; path=/; max-age=900
server: Apache
x-powered-by: PHP/7.2
set-cookie: xxxxx=0919c5563fc87d601ab99e2f85d4217d; expires=Fri, 04-Oct-2019 12:04:51 GMT; Max-Age=14400; path=/; secure; HttpOnly
vary: Accept-Encoding

Trying to go deeper with the chrome://net-export/ and https://netlog-viewer.appspot.com tools is telling me the request ends with a RST_STREAM :

t=123354 [st=5170]    HTTP2_SESSION_RECV_RST_STREAM
                      --> error_code = "2 (INTERNAL_ERROR)"
                      --> stream_id = 1

For what I read in this other post, "In HTTP/2, if the client wants to abort the request, it sends a RST_STREAM. When the server receives a RST_STREAM, it will stop sending DATA frames to the client, thereby stopping the response (or the download). The connection is still usable for other requests, and requests/responses that were concurrent with the one that has been aborted may continue to progress. [...] It is possible that by the time the RST_STREAM travels from the client to the server, the whole content of the request is in transit and will arrive to the client, which will discard it. However, for large response contents, sending a RST_STREAM may have a good chance to arrive to the server before the whole response content is sent, and therefore will save bandwidth."

The described behavior is the same as the one I can observe. But that would mean the browser is the culprit, and then I wouldn't understand why it happens on two identical pages with one having a 200 header and the other a 404 (same goes if I disable JS).
completion:
The net::ERR_HTTP2_PROTOCOL_ERROR is an error message that appears in web browsers when there is a problem with the HTTP/2 protocol during a network request. HTTP/2 is the latest version of the HTTP protocol that is used to transfer data between a web server and a browser.

This error typically occurs when there is a communication issue between the browser and the server, causing the HTTP/2 protocol to fail. It can be caused by various factors, such as a misconfiguration on the server, incompatible server or browser software, or network connectivity problems.

When this error occurs, it usually means that the browser is unable to establish a successful connection with the server using the HTTP/2 protocol. As a result, the requested webpage or resource cannot be loaded.

To resolve this issue, you can try the following troubleshooting steps:

1. Clear your browser cache and cookies.
2. Disable browser extensions or plugins that might interfere with the HTTP/2 protocol.
3. Restart your browser or try using a different browser.
4. Check your internet connection and ensure it is stable.
5. Contact the website administrator or server provider to check for any server-side issues or misconfigurations.

If the problem persists, it is recommended to seek further assistance from technical support or consult with a web developer.

HTTP Error 500 (Internal Server Error): An unexpected condition was encountered while the server was attempting to fulfil the request.

I have checked my /etc/php5/apache2/php.ini file and as far as I can tell error reporting should be set up. The contents of the file (regarding errors) are:

;    display_errors
;      Default Value: On
;      Development Value: On
;      Production Value: Off

;    display_startup_errors
;      Default Value: Off
;      Development Value: On
;      Production Value: Off

;    error_reporting
;      Default Value: E_ALL & ~E_NOTICE
;      Development Value: E_ALL | E_STRICT
;      Production Value: E_ALL & ~E_DEPRECATED

Can anyone advise? If I try something like $obj = new ObjectDoesntExist; it doesn't tell me Fatal error: Class 'ObjectDoesntExist' it gives me a server 500 error.

Any advise?

* The modules I have installed are: mysql-server mysql-client apache2 php5 libapache2-mod-php5 phpmyadmin. Other than that it is a completely base install of Ubuntu Server 12.04 LTS

EDIT: If I use ini_set('display_errors', '1'); at the start of my script it displays errors as normal, but how do I enable this site wide?
completion:
If PHP is not displaying errors and you are getting an Internal Server Error (500), it means that the error reporting is disabled in the PHP configuration or there is a syntax error in your code that is causing the server to fail.

To enable error reporting in PHP, you can try the following steps:

1. Check the PHP configuration file (php.ini) and make sure that the `display_errors` directive is set to `On`. If it is set to `Off`, change it to `On`. If you don't have access to the php.ini file, you can try adding the following line at the beginning of your PHP script:

   ```php
   ini_set('display_errors', 1);
   error_reporting(E_ALL);
   ```

2. If you have made changes to the php.ini file or added the above code to your script, restart your web server to apply the changes.

3. If error reporting is still not working, check if there is a custom error handling function defined in your code or in a framework you are using. This function may be suppressing the error messages. Remove or modify the custom error handling function to display errors.

4. If none of the above steps work, there might be a syntax error or fatal error in your code that is causing the server to fail. In this case, you can try enabling error logging to a file by adding the following lines to your PHP script:

   ```php
   ini_set('log_errors', 1);
   ini_set('error_log', '/path/to/error.log');
   ```

   Replace `/path/to/error.log` with the actual path where you want to store the error log file. This will help you identify the specific error that is causing the Internal Server Error.

Remember to remove or disable error reporting and logging in a production environment for security reasons.

completion:
Hashing a session fingerprint is not always necessary, but it can provide additional security and privacy benefits in certain scenarios.

A session fingerprint is a unique identifier generated based on various attributes of a user's session, such as IP address, user agent, and other relevant information. It is used to track and identify a user's session across multiple requests.

Hashing the session fingerprint can offer the following advantages:

1. Privacy: Hashing the session fingerprint can help protect the user's privacy by obfuscating the original fingerprint. Instead of storing the actual fingerprint, only the hashed version is stored, making it harder for an attacker or unauthorized party to reverse-engineer the original fingerprint.

2. Security: Hashing adds an extra layer of security by making it difficult for an attacker to manipulate or forge a session fingerprint. If the fingerprint is not hashed, an attacker could potentially modify the fingerprint to impersonate another user's session.

3. Storage efficiency: Hashing reduces the storage space required to store session fingerprints. Hash functions generate fixed-length outputs, regardless of the input size. Storing hashed fingerprints can be more efficient than storing the original fingerprints, especially when dealing with large amounts of data.

However, there may be cases where hashing the session fingerprint is not necessary. For example, if the session fingerprint does not contain any sensitive information and there are no privacy concerns, hashing may not provide significant benefits. Additionally, if the session fingerprint is already sufficiently secure and tamper-proof, hashing might be redundant.

Ultimately, the decision to hash a session fingerprint depends on the specific requirements and risks associated with the application or system in question.

title: Set Dynamic Base Url in CodeIgniter
text:
I need to set dynamic base url in codeigniter due to few following reasons.

  • single application accessible from multiple domains
  • ip address may change due to dhcp (locally)
completion:
To set a dynamic base URL in CodeIgniter, you can use the `config.php` file located in the `application/config` directory.

1. Open the `config.php` file.
2. Look for the following line of code:

```php
$config['base_url'] = 'http://localhost/your_project/';

3. Replace the static URL with a dynamic one. For example, you can use the `$_SERVER['HTTP_HOST']` variable to get the current host name:

```php
$config['base_url'] = 'http://' . $_SERVER['HTTP_HOST'] . '/';
```

This will set the base URL dynamically based on the current host.

Note: Make sure to include the trailing slash at the end of the base URL.

You can also set the base URL dynamically based on other conditions or variables. Just make sure to assign the desired URL to the `$config['base_url']` variable before using it in your application.

title: what is the "::" notation in php used for?
text:
I am looking through some php code and I see this "::" notation that i have no idea what it means...also what the & in the front of the call

$mainframe =& JFactory::getApplication('site');
$sql="SELECT rt.member_id ,rt.commission,rt.sales,kt.store_id,kt.user_id FROM jos_report
rt JOIN jos_kingdom_tickets kt WHERE rt.member_id=kt.ticket_id";
$db =& JFactory::getDBO();

thanks in advance
completion:
In PHP, the "::" notation is used to access static methods, constants, and properties of a class without creating an instance of that class. It is called the scope resolution operator.

Here are some common uses of "::" notation in PHP:

1. Accessing static methods: You can call a static method of a class using the "::" notation. For example, if you have a class named "MyClass" with a static method "myMethod", you can call it like this: "MyClass::myMethod()".

2. Accessing static properties: Similarly, you can access static properties of a class using "::". For example, if you have a static property named "myProperty" in the "MyClass" class, you can access it like this: "MyClass::$myProperty".

3. Accessing constants: You can access class constants using "::" notation. Constants are defined using the "const" keyword within a class. For example, if you have a constant named "MY_CONSTANT" in the "MyClass" class, you can access it like this: "MyClass::MY_CONSTANT".

Note that "::" is only used for static members and constants, not for accessing non-static members or invoking non-static methods. For those, you need to create an instance of the class using the "new" keyword.

And even more unfortunate is that I am running my WAMP server on Windows XP (but I am developing for a UNIX environment) and none of the tutorials can get gettext working properly for me. From the manual page, it appears that it's a different process on a Windows environment. I've tried out some of the solutions in the comments but I still can't get it to work! I've spent many hours on this, hopefully someone can point me in the right direction to get this thing to work! (And I'm sure there are others out there who share my frustration.) So far with my setup, I'm only getting output "Hello World!" whereas I should be getting the translated string.

Here is my setup/code so far:

    define('LC_MESSAGES', 6);
}

$locale = "deu_DEU"; // apparently the locales are different on a WINDOWS platform

completion:
To use PHP gettext on Windows, you need to follow these steps:

1. Install the gettext extension for PHP:
   - Download the appropriate version of the gettext extension from the PECL website (https://pecl.php.net/package/gettext).
   - Extract the downloaded file and copy the `php_gettext.dll` file to your PHP extensions directory (e.g., `C:\php\ext`).
   - Open your PHP configuration file (php.ini) and add the following line at the end:
     ```
     extension=php_gettext.dll
     ```
   - Save the changes and restart your web server.

2. Install the gettext library:
   - Download the gettext library for Windows from the GNU gettext website (https://mlocati.github.io/articles/gettext-iconv-windows.html).
   - Extract the downloaded file and copy the contents to a directory on your system (e.g., `C:\gettext`).

3. Set the environment variable:
   - Open the System Properties window by right-clicking on the Computer icon and selecting "Properties".
   - Click on "Advanced system settings" and then click on the "Environment Variables" button.
   - Under the "System variables" section, click on the "New" button.
   - Enter `GETTEXT_HOME` as the variable name and the path to the gettext directory (e.g., `C:\gettext`) as the variable value.
   - Click "OK" to save the changes.

4. Restart your web server to apply the changes.

5. Start using gettext in your PHP code:
   - Create a `.po` file for each language you want to support. You can use a tool like Poedit (https://poedit.net/) to create and edit these files.
   - Use the `bindtextdomain()` function to set the directory where your `.po` files are located:
     ```php
     bindtextdomain('myapp', 'path/to/po/files');
     ```
   - Use the `textdomain()` function to set the domain for your translations:
     ```php
     textdomain('myapp');
     ```
   - Use the `gettext()` function to translate your strings:
     ```php
     echo gettext('Hello, world!');
     ```

That's it! You should now be able to use PHP gettext on Windows.

$users = User::whereDate('created_at', '=', '2022-01-01')->get();

$users = User::whereDate('created_at', '>', '2022-01-01')->get();

Note that the `whereDate` method is available in Laravel 5.2 and above.

completion:
To redirect to a 404 page using .htaccess, you can use the following RewriteRule:

```
RewriteEngine On
RewriteRule ^(.*)$ /404-page.html [L,R=404]
```

This rule will redirect all requests to the 404-page.html file and return a 404 status code. Make sure to replace "/404-page.html" with the actual path to your 404 page.

PHP opcode is a low-level representation of PHP code that is generated by the PHP interpreter during the compilation process. It is a set of instructions that the PHP engine can directly execute. 

When PHP code is executed, it goes through several stages: 

1. Lexing: The PHP code is broken down into tokens, which are the smallest units of the language.
2. Parsing: The tokens are organized into a syntax tree, representing the structure of the code.
3. Compilation: The syntax tree is converted into opcode instructions, which are stored in memory.
4. Execution: The PHP engine reads and executes the opcode instructions one by one.

The opcode instructions are not directly executed as binary code by the CPU. Instead, they are executed by the PHP engine's virtual machine, which interprets and executes the opcode instructions. The virtual machine is responsible for translating the opcode instructions into machine code that the CPU can understand and execute.

So, the PHP opcode acts as an intermediate representation between the PHP code and the actual binary code executed by the CPU. It allows the PHP engine to efficiently execute PHP code without the need for direct compilation to machine code.

title: array_map vs loop and operation
text:
Using:

for($i=1; $i<= 10000; ++$i) {
    $arrayOfNumbers[] = rand(1, 99999);
}

Can some explain why there is such a speed difference:

array_map(array($maxHeap, 'insert'), $arrayOfNumbers);
# Avg Time: 0.92856907844543s

# against

foreach($arrayOfNumbers as $number) {
    $maxHeap->insert($number);
}
# Avg Time: 1.3148670101166

$maxHeap being an object class MaxHeap extends SplMaxHeap
completion:
The main difference between using `array_map` and a loop with an operation is the level of abstraction and readability.

`array_map` is a higher-level function that allows you to apply a callback function to each element of an array. It takes care of iterating over the array and applying the callback function, returning a new array with the modified values. This can make your code more concise and easier to read, especially when dealing with complex operations.

On the other hand, using a loop and an operation gives you more control and flexibility. You can explicitly define the iteration process and perform any operation you want on each element. This can be useful when you need to perform additional logic or modify the array in a specific way that is not easily achieved with `array_map`.

In terms of performance, `array_map` can be faster than a loop in some cases, especially when dealing with large arrays. This is because `array_map` can take advantage of internal optimizations and parallel processing. However, the difference in performance is usually negligible unless you are working with very large datasets.

In summary, `array_map` is a convenient and concise way to apply a callback function to each element of an array, while a loop and an operation give you more control and flexibility. The choice between the two depends on the specific requirements of your code and your preference for readability versus control.

title: How to install a specific version of package using Composer?

completion:
To install a specific version of a package using Composer, you can use the following command:

```
composer require vendor/package:version
```

Replace `vendor/package` with the name of the package you want to install, and `version` with the specific version you want to install.

For example, to install version 1.2.3 of the `monolog/monolog` package, you would run:

```
composer require monolog/monolog:1.2.3
```

Composer will then download and install the specified version of the package and update your `composer.json` and `composer.lock` files accordingly.

completion:
If PHP doesn't see the MySQL extension, it means that the extension is not enabled or installed in your PHP configuration. Here are a few steps you can take to resolve this issue:

1. Check if the MySQL extension is installed: Run the following command in your terminal or command prompt to see if the MySQL extension is installed:
   ```
   php -m | grep mysql
   ```

2. Enable the MySQL extension: Open your PHP configuration file (php.ini) and search for the following line:
   ```
   ;extension=mysqli
   ```
   Uncomment the line by removing the semicolon at the beginning:
   ```

   ```

   ```
   sudo apt-get install php-mysql
   ```
   After installation, restart your web server.

4. Verify the extension: After enabling or installing the MySQL extension, create a PHP file with the following code to verify if the extension is working:
   ```php
   <?php
   phpinfo();
   ?>
   ```
   Open the file in your web browser and search for "mysql" in the output. If you find it, the extension is now enabled and working.

If none of the above steps work, it's possible that your PHP version is not compatible with the MySQL extension. In that case, you may need to consider using an alternative extension like MySQLi or PDO for database connectivity.

The `tee` command reads from standard input and writes to both standard output and one or more files. Here's an example of how you can use `tee` to achieve this: ```bash your-command | tee output.txt ``` In this example, `your-command` represents the command whose output you want to stream. The `|` symbol is a pipe, which redirects the output of `your-command` to `tee`. `output.txt` is the file where the output will be saved. By default, `tee` will display the output in the terminal and write it to the file. If you want to prevent the output from being displayed in the terminal, you can redirect the standard output to `/dev/null` like this: ```bash your-command | tee output.txt >/dev/null ``` This will only write the output to the file `output.txt` and not display it in the terminal. If you want to stream the output to multiple files, you can specify multiple file names separated by spaces: ```bash your-command | tee output1.txt output2.txt ``` This will write the output to both `output1.txt` and `output2.txt`. To view the streamed output in a browser, you can create a simple HTML file that includes the content of the output file. Here's an example: ```html Output

completion:
To prepare for debug and production environments in Yii2, you can follow these steps:

1. Enable Debug Mode: In the `web/index.php` file, set the `YII_DEBUG` constant to `true` to enable debug mode. This will display detailed error messages and stack traces in case of any errors.

2. Disable Debug Mode: In the `web/index.php` file, set the `YII_DEBUG` constant to `false` to disable debug mode. This will hide detailed error messages and stack traces in the production environment.

3. Set Environment Variables: Create a `.env` file in the root directory of your Yii2 application and define environment-specific variables. For example, you can define database connection details, API keys, or any other configuration values that may vary between environments.

4. Configure Database Connection: In the `config/db.php` file, configure the database connection settings based on the environment. You can use the environment variables defined in the `.env` file to set the database credentials dynamically.

5. Use Different Configuration Files: Create separate configuration files for each environment (e.g., `config/main-local.php` for the local environment and `config/main-prod.php` for the production environment). In the `web/index.php` file, load the appropriate configuration file based on the environment.

6. Set Error Handling: Customize the error handling in the `config/web.php` file. You can configure error logging, error pages, and error handling behavior based on the environment.

7. Optimize Performance: In the `config/web.php` file, enable Yii2's performance optimizations for the production environment. This includes enabling asset bundling and minification, enabling Gii caching, and configuring the cache component.

8. Use Version Control: Use a version control system like Git to manage your codebase. Create separate branches for development, staging, and production environments. This allows you to easily switch between different environments and deploy changes to production.

By following these steps, you can effectively prepare your Yii2 application for both debug and production environments.

2. Apache configuration: Check your Apache configuration files (e.g., `.htaccess`, `httpd.conf`) for any directives that might add the header. Look for lines containing `Header set Pragma "no-cache"` or similar.

3. Caching modules: If you have any caching modules enabled in Apache (e.g., mod_cache, mod_expires), they might be automatically adding the "Pragma:no-cache" header. Check your Apache configuration for any caching-related directives.

4. PHP frameworks or libraries: If you are using a PHP framework or library, it might have built-in functionality to add cache-control headers. Check the documentation or configuration files of the framework/library to see if there is any setting related to cache-control headers.

5. Reverse proxy or CDN: If you are using a reverse proxy or a content delivery network (CDN) in front of your Apache server, they might be adding the "Pragma:no-cache" header. Check the configuration of your reverse proxy or CDN to see if there are any cache-related settings.

By investigating these possibilities, you should be able to identify the source of the "Pragma:no-cache" header in your response headers.

title: How to handle IPv6 Addresses in PHP?
text:
After searching around somewhat thoroughly, I noticed a slight lack of functions in PHP for handling IPv6. For my own personal satisfaction I created a few functions to help the transition.

The IPv6ToLong() function is a temporary solution to that brought up here: How to store IPv6-compatible address in a relational database. It will split the IP in to two integers and return them in an array.

/**
 * Convert an IPv4 address to IPv6
 *
 * @param string IP Address in dot notation (192.168.1.100)
 * @return string IPv6 formatted address or false if invalid input
 */
function IPv4To6($Ip) {
    static $Mask = '::ffff:'; // This tells IPv6 it has an IPv4 address
    $IPv6 = (strpos($Ip, '::') === 0);
    $IPv4 = (strpos($Ip, '.') > 0);

    if (!$IPv4 && !$IPv6) return false;
    if ($IPv6 && $IPv4) $Ip = substr($Ip, strrpos($Ip, ':')+1); // Strip IPv4 Compatibility notation
    elseif (!$IPv4) return $Ip; // Seems to be IPv6 already?
    $Ip = array_pad(explode('.', $Ip), 4, 0);
    if (count($Ip) > 4) return false;
    for ($i = 0; $i < 4; $i++) if ($Ip[$i] > 255) return false;

    $Part7 = base_convert(($Ip[0] * 256) + $Ip[1], 10, 16);
    $Part8 = base_convert(($Ip[2] * 256) + $Ip[3], 10, 16);
    return $Mask.$Part7.':'.$Part8;
}

/**
 * Replace '::' with appropriate number of ':0'
 */
function ExpandIPv6Notation($Ip) {
    if (strpos($Ip, '::') !== false)
        $Ip = str_replace('::', str_repeat(':0', 8 - substr_count($Ip, ':')).':', $Ip);
    if (strpos($Ip, ':') === 0) $Ip = '0'.$Ip;
    return $Ip;
}

/**
 * Convert IPv6 address to an integer
 *
 * Optionally split in to two parts.
 *
 * @see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/420680/
 */
function IPv6ToLong($Ip, $DatabaseParts= 2) {
    $Ip = ExpandIPv6Notation($Ip);
    $Parts = explode(':', $Ip);
    $Ip = array('', '');
    for ($i = 0; $i < 4; $i++) $Ip[0] .= str_pad(base_convert($Parts[$i], 16, 2), 16, 0, STR_PAD_LEFT);
    for ($i = 4; $i < 8; $i++) $Ip[1] .= str_pad(base_convert($Parts[$i], 16, 2), 16, 0, STR_PAD_LEFT);

    if ($DatabaseParts == 2)
            return array(base_convert($Ip[0], 2, 10), base_convert($Ip[1], 2, 10));
    else    return base_convert($Ip[0], 2, 10) + base_convert($Ip[1], 2, 10);
}

For these functions I typically implement them by calling this function first:

 *

 * @return string|long The IP Address
 */

    $Ip = '0.0.0.0';
    // [snip: deleted some dangerous code not relevant to question. @webb]
    if (isset($_SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR']) && $_SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR'] != '')

$data = 'iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABwAAAASCAMAAAB/2U7WAAAABl'
       . 'BMVEUAAAD///+l2Z/dAAAASUlEQVR4XqWQUQoAIAxC2/0vXZDr'

completion:
The size of a base64-encoded string depends on the size of the file being encoded. 

To calculate the size of the base64-encoded string, you can use the following formula:

```
encodedSize = ceil(fileSize / 3) * 4
```

Where `fileSize` is the size of the file in bytes and `encodedSize` is the size of the base64-encoded string in bytes.

Note that the result of this calculation will be an approximation, as base64 encoding adds padding characters to the end of the string to ensure it is a multiple of 4 characters long.

title: Is it possible to restrict what commands php can pass through exec at an OS level?
text:
I am currently hosting a Drupal 6 site on a CentOS machine. The Drupal (CMS) configuration contains a few dozen third-party modules that should not be forked as a general best coding practice. However, some of these modules make use of the php exec command in order to function properly.

The site allows for admins to embed php code snippets in any page via a UI configuration, granted that they have access to the php code input format. I need to keep this input format available to admins because there are several nodes (pages) and panel panes that make use of small, harmless php code snippets, like embedding a specific form into the content region, for example.

The issue is that if someone were to compromise an admin account, then they could run arbitrary php code on the site, and thus run shell commands via php's exec, passthru, etc. Is there any way, from an operating system level, to restrict what shell commands php can pass through to the machine? Could this be done via restricting file permissions to some programs from php?

Note: I cannot use the php.ini disable_functions directive as I still need exec to function normally for many cases, where modules make use of certain shell commands, like video encoding, for example.
completion:
Yes, it is possible to restrict what commands PHP can pass through the `exec` function at an operating system (OS) level. This can be achieved by configuring the server's security settings and implementing proper access controls.

Here are a few approaches to restrict commands passed through `exec`:

1. Disable `exec` function: You can disable the `exec` function in PHP by modifying the `php.ini` configuration file. Locate the `disable_functions` directive and add `exec` to the list. This will prevent PHP from executing any command using `exec`.

2. Use `safe_mode`: PHP's `safe_mode` feature allows you to restrict the execution of certain functions, including `exec`, based on the directory in which the PHP script resides. By enabling `safe_mode` and configuring it properly, you can limit the commands that can be executed through `exec`.

3. Whitelist allowed commands: Instead of completely disabling `exec`, you can create a whitelist of allowed commands that can be executed through `exec`. This can be done by implementing a custom function that checks the command against the whitelist before passing it to `exec`. Any command not present in the whitelist will be rejected.

4. Implement proper input validation: Before passing any command to `exec`, ensure that you perform thorough input validation and sanitization. This helps prevent command injection attacks by blocking any malicious or unauthorized commands.

It is important to note that the specific steps to implement these restrictions may vary depending on the server configuration and the PHP version being used. It is recommended to consult the PHP documentation and seek professional advice to ensure proper implementation and security.
